description:
YAS! YAAAAS! AZTECA BURRITO FTW!! Is it possible to have romantic feelings for a burrito? You tell me. Go and eat the Azteca Burrito (which is basically an "enchilada-style burrito" or "burrito mojado") at Mexico au Parc and tell me you don't wanna put a ring on it. I dare you. I'm not saying this to scare you or raise your expectations, I just want you to be prepared for the strong emotions you're gonna feel. It's cheesy and juicy and towards the end a little bit messy and gooey--but in a good way. I like to get extra cheese on mine and I'll be honest, sometimes when I feel like being bad, I'll get some guac on the side. The best part: it's under $10. Yes, it IS possible to have lunch for less than $10 in SF!! Who needs a spouse when you can have this hot mess?! (Please don't tell my husband I said this. I mean, he's alright, but he's no Azteca Burrito.)

Can you get better Mexican in SF? Of course you can. The sky is the limit! But when you're hangry AF and you don't wanna walk too far to get lunch (especially bc you fear the risk of bumping into your ex who works down the street or whatever) this is more than enough.  

Tip: For the best experience, go BEFORE NOON. I'm talking like 11 or 11:30. It's never too early for a burrito anyways.

My reason for deducting 1 star: The two-line system can be confusing at first and sometimes it takes a while for your order to come out. I've maybe had one burrito that maybe wasn't as "fresh" tasting, but that's life. Can't let one and burrito ruin the whole establishment. The staff are friendly and service is always great.
author: Rie U.

description:
I work near South Park and recently decided to give Mexico au Parc a chance. The restaurant was not busy when I went in around 11 AM but it still took about 10 minutes to make my order. The two ordering lines were also a little confusing. I ordered two steak tacos with a side of mexican rice. The rice was delicious but the tacos were subpar. The steak was dry and the tacos lacked flavor and freshness. 

I will likely not return to Mexico au Parc.
author: Katie C.

description:
Walking in, there's 2 different lines. Grilled and a made to order one. Went to the made to order one again. Ordered tacos once and this time an azteca burrito.  

Service is good, 2 ladies work the made to order line. They always ask you for sour cream, guac, and salsa and if you say you only want 1, you'll still be charged for ordering everything. So it's either you're all in, or you out!  There's a lot of different types of meats to pick from which is cool. I even saw a tofu option for the vegetarian/vegans. 

Quality of the food/meats are OK but the menu pricing is super misleading. It has happen twice where the menu prices bamboozle you once you pay at the register, after you already ordered your food so you don't really have a choice.. I don't eat out a lot in the city so I don't really like that uncertainty in pricing here. Azteca burrito is listed to be about $10ish bucks on the menu. I go to pay and the total was about $14. I asked for a receipt later on (after a couple customers already gone after me) but was told it was too late already.. Chips and a salsa bar are here too so that's a cool touch if you dine in.
author: Tiffany Z.

description: Lines can get very long! Come here before 12:00PM and you should be good to go.  There are two lines: one for burritos and one for the grill.  For a shorter line, you can go to the grill.  The burrito line is longer but they are making a burrito as it goes.  In my experience, the grill tends to be a tad bit quicker, so grab your quesadillas!
author: Justin L.

description: Best Mexican in town. Their fried chicken burritos and steak quesadillas are amazing.
author: Cansin Y.

description: I came here for lunch on Wednesday with a couple of coworkers to quickly grab a bite to bring back to the office. From a recommendation, I decided to go for their nachos. Not being too hungry, I decided to get their Azteca Nachos which comes with cheese, beans, guacamole, and sour cream unlike their Super Nachos which comes with a choice of meat. They gave a generous portion of every ingredient which led to a filling and satisfying lunch meal. They also have an awesome looking grill menu which has to be ordered at the cashier which I'll definitely give a try.
author: Joshua M.

description: I took a friend into the city for a doctor's appointment and decided to get some Mexican food.  I ordered the chicken tostada with chips and salsa.  The chips were a little less than average.  The salsa was ok and the tostada was average.  I'll try a different place next time I'm in the city.
author: Jan F.

description:
I like this place because it's close to work, cheaper than the other closest Mexican spot and located in the beautifully renovated South Park area!

Beyond that the food is okay. It's good for a quick lunch fix and to sit outside and it's fresh, but don't expect to be blown away.

The variety of salsas to choose from is nice (being the condiment queen) but I really only like one and found myself wanting to add salt and peppers to the others.

One thing I will say is I haven't tried the food from the grill line yet. The shrimp fajitas do sound mighty tasty. That could definitely raise my rating! I'll keep you posted for next time...
author: Heather H.

description: Yassssss! One of the best burrito spots I've been to in SF..... (besides El Farolitos in the mission). They were clean with great customer service. The ambiance is cool and you can eat outside where there is a park. I will definitely be back.
author: M W.

description: Okay, I have had the opportunity to eat at yet another gem of a restaurant. Let me first start by saying the restaurant was very clean and well organized. Secondly the cooking and food prep area was equally organized with fresh vegetables being prepared and the salsa bar although small was very clean and nicely laid out. Now for the really good part.... The meal with fresh ingredients was very tasty. This place is definitely a restaurant I would like to eat at again.
author: Mike M.

description: OKAY, this place is WAY underrated! Hands down the BEST vegan (maybe vegan?) burrito I've ever had. I ONLY went to this place because I happened to temporarily work in SF. Original Bay Area folks know, if you're from Oakland and currently live in Oakland, you DON'T go to SF unless absolutely necessary and there are no alternatives. (At least the folks I know, lol). I took a Lyft to Mexico Au Parc on my lunch break to try it for the first time. The location is super cute. There is a park right across the street that is nice if you have the time to sit and eat. Now, what I didn't expect was a line outside of the restaurant! I had to ask about why there were two lines and quickly caught on that you could order from the grill in a separate line, so I jumped in that line, which happened to be shorter that day. I explained that I wanted a vegan burrito (listen, I'm not that strict of a vegan, so if something is in a tortilla that isn't vegan - I DON'T WANT TO KNOW ABOUT IT).  I got a grilled veggie burrito which optionally has broccoli in it, which I wanted nothing to do with. I also added guac, and asked for no sour cream. They cook the veggies right next to the meats, so ... you should know that. They give you a small bag of chips (similar size to any other Mexican restaurants). Getting salsa is kind of a challenge, simply because there are a ton of people and everyone is moving everywhere. I do not know if they marinate these vegetables in a literal cow or season it with some sort of unicorn blend but this burrito is effing delicious for no understandable damn reason at all. Like, WHAT?! How!? So, of course, a Lyft ride + Long lines + crazy bustle + delicious burrito = I went back 4 times in a row.  Its Sunday, they aren't open. They are only open during standard business hours to serve employees of the surrounding offices... and here I am.. ready to travel to SF on a Sunday for this grilled veggie burrito, because they do things right. Tip: Do yourself a favor and call in your order so you can prance in and pass up everyone in line and wait (yep, wait) like 5 minutes instead of 20 minutes for you food. Happy Lunching.
author: Nik N.

description:
Fantastic. Friendly service, great food for a great price.

They have a Hawaiian style pork and pineapple burrito that haunts my dreams in the best way.
author: Wil W.

description: Been here a few times and have been pleased every time. I've only tried the al pastor quesadilla, chorizo breakfast burrito and horchata here. Portions are huge, so don't be deterred by the still somewhat expensive prices. You can pay extra for guacamole and sour cream inside your quesadilla, which I highly recommend. The quesadilla lasted me 2 meals because it was so huge and filling! I also recommend the chorizo breakfast burrito - I had half of it for breakfast, and I was full until the early afternoon and only ate half of my lunch. The salsas here are also fresh and yummy, but could be a bit spicier. However, I don't really recommend the horchata here - it's a bit powdery and doesn't taste like it's made from scratch.
author: Victoria L.

description: Delicious. I shared the veggie super burrito with refried beans and without sour cream. It was very good. The beans were delicious. My mother had the tostada which she enjoyed. Their salsa is delicious. I also had a taco al pastor which was good but the meat was a little sweet for me. I recommend and will return again.
author: Rude G.

description: Meh Mexican food. I did a "burrito bowl" in order to skip the tortilla, but the lady barely gave me anything. I paid $10 for very little food. The salsas weren't all that tasty. One of the red salsas was good.
author: Shruti D.

description:
Floppy burritos make me sad. Oversalted pork also makes me sad.

I came after lunch when it was quiet, and the lady building my burrito stopped to talk to her coworker in the middle of making my order, seemingly forgetting about me. Then she continued filling it without asking what my preferences were.

For better, affordable Mexican food in the area, check out the food truck parked half a block away by the gas station during lunch hours.
author: Sarah H.

description:
This place always got crowded on weekdays so I had to check it out.

I've ordered/visited 5+ times now and ordered around the menu. I always manage to satisfy my Mexican-fix, but am never really happy with the taste.

It's possible that I've been spoiled after living next to so many great digs in the Mission, but I just feel like there's nothing special about Mexico au Parc.

You will get a lot for the money, but not a great tasting meal. 

Their super tacos are tasty, and large - the quality of meat is decent. The burritos are meh quality. The staff has been unnecessarily rude and impatient with me and friends multiple times, and the design of the restaurant is poorly thought out.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Really loved coming here for lunch when I worked in South Park. Very fresh ingredients, super nice staff and the food is delicious! I've had the nachos, tacos and burrito (all vegetarian) and all were delicious. It gets crowded for lunch to the point where the line flows out of the door down the sidewalk but it moves pretty quickly. Simple, tasty, inexpensive lunch in the area!

Minus one star because of all the pretentious, tech bros either on their phones talking very loudly and their lack of awareness of their surroundings. I love this place but many of the people who frequent need to kindly jump off the Bay Bridge.

Highly recommended!
author: Angela H.

description:
Favorite Mexican food in the area. Really nice staff.

MOLE MOLE MOLE. If you don't like the sweet, savory, umami deliciousness that is mole, I feel bad for you. Do you even food, bro? Mole tacos, mole burritos, hell, even mole in a bowl with nothing else. Om nom noms.

I've been working in SoMa for 2 years now and this is by far my favorite Mexican place in the area. 

Insider tip: Get here by 11:45 to beat the line. Oh, and did I mention "mole"?
author: Katie N.

description:
Good value for the SOMA area.  This place does get packed though so you're probably better off getting to go.  The staff works quick and are friendly though.  I also like how they have a salsa bar & don't charge extra for chips and salsa.  

The flavors are a little on the bland side though, but my dining companion, Janice C. said that's because they don't put that much salt then, & that's good for everyone's blood pressure!

I got the Aztec burrito which is their version of an enchilada burrito with guac and sour cream.  It was huge and I believe around $8.  I got it with carnitas which were moist.  She got the chicken mole which she enjoyed but actually was in a green verde looking like sauce.  Again since they don't put much salt on the food it was a little on the bland side.  It's all give and take, right?  It's a good option to have in the pricey SOMA area.  I would be open to coming back to try a different burrito or another item.
author: Cat C.

description: The place is layed out kind of oddly, and the prices are on the steep side.  The value of this place is in that they dont shy away from more labor intensive dishes like mole, and cochinita. Having said that - my boring veggie burrito was A-OK.
author: Oleg H.

description: I'm reviewing purely for the rice, refried beans, and tamale. I've gone by a couple of times to get a to go of these side orders and its been tasty even though it was later in the day. Quality was still nice and not dried out. The lady that works there is very nice and its actually a fresher tamale that she heats up instead of the one on display. It's chicken and nicely textured and tender. Rice and beans are good too. I like the salsa bar on the side as well.
author: Tao Tao W.

description: A solid lunch spot and some of the best quick Mexican food in the neighborhood! The line can be pretty long around lunch time on a weekday, but they get you through it pretty quickly. The salsa bar is indeed "notable" and the salsas they have are all very flavorful. I had a carnitas super burrito which was about as good as one from any typical spot in the Mission. The menu has quite a few different kinds of meat fillings and a few different dishes so I will absolutely come back here many times to try more of the menu. I'm super excited to try their torta!
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
+ great location right alongside the charming little South Park 
- I wanted a torta but they didn't have any bread
- ordered a regular burrito; they definitely skimped on filling it up - was mostly tortilla! Also, chicken was not very tasty
+ selection of salsas
author: Jason T.

description: I was the first customer in the door at 8am and it took them 30 minutes to make a breakfast burrito. People have things to do, and if it's going to take 30 minutes at least give me the courtesy of a heads up.
author: Charles R.

description:
Hearty authentic food with a variety of options. 
Everything has always been super fresh. I've had lunch here a handful of times over the last year. 
Great lunch spot!!!

I am super full and I had lunch over 2 hours ago. 

There are several burrito places nearby and if I don't some fusion-styles burrito, this place is my fave. Gotta try it!
author: Shawnee J.

description:
3.5 stars

A cheerful space with efficient workers and healthy Mexican eats get my stamp of approval.

Yes, indeed. You heard me. I ate HEALTHY here! 

I enjoyed the green chicken mole plate with rice, black beans and a side salad which can be had for only $10! (SF standard nowadays!) Do grab extra verde salsa from the not-so-impressive, but decent salsa bar and pour it on top of your food. Personally, I found my dish a little bit bland, but I was actually glad that it wasn't over salted. They throw a bag of chips for free, I know, it doesn't exactly go along the line of our healthy theme .. but I'm only human ;)

Mexico au Parc fills the void of South of the Border cuisine in this area. I like it. Maybe next time, I'll try one of their huge burritos.
author: Janice C.

description:
Stopped in for a breakfast burrito. A cook was prepping tomatoes on the grill and I noticed a tomato with a huge mold spot. I pointed it out and was dismissed "No mold! No mold!"

I insisted and cook removed the tomato from the grill without any acknowledgement of me or the issue of serving moldy produce.

The messed up the order on my to-go breakfast burrito which was meh at best. I won't be back.

Food safety is no joke!
author: Sam F.

description:
For my money, the best lunch place in the neighborhood. It's not so much that it's the best food (though it is some of the best food I've had at any price in the immediate area), it's that it's super cheap, not that unhealthy, and fast. Some say it's a bit bland, but I think it's all a matter of asking for what you want. If you like it spicier, for example, then ask for more of the spicy salsa, which I find plenty flavorful and far from overpoweringly hot.

I also think the staff are nice, and the horchata's both good and cheap. I'm probably grading on a bit of a curve to give it five stars considering how good food is in the City, but it can be seriously a challenge to find good cheap food in startup-ville near AT&T park. This is definitely my go-to place when I want a good meal for cheap in South Beach.
author: Nathan P.

description: Incredibly slow in the morning, I don't recommend breakfast here at all. Decent lunch with a variety of options.
author: Cody R.

description: Yes love this place. When I went to AAU, everyday I got the quesadilla with guac and sourcream inside it before they grilled it and it was always perfect and now I never have quesadillas any other way. Delicious. Thank you for your always great service!
author: Chelsea K.

description: Decent food but the line can be very slow. I don't blame the employees it's mostly the clientele.
author: Nick J.

description:
This is a review for the back grill. Yes, there is a grill in the back where everything is made-to-order so don't be a fool and get in the long line that forms up front for all that ready-made stuff!

The carnitas and chorizo tacos here are flavorful and delicious when it comes sizzling off the grill. Although even without a line, the back grill still takes a while. Be prepared for a 15-20 minute wait during the lunch rush. Cash only if your order is less than $10.
author: Catherine C.

description: I like the food, and most of the staff are fine, but there are one or two employees that simply do not listen to what you order, and then will cop an attitude, and act extremely rude and vengeful if you ask them to remake the order.  I had avoided the place for a long time, because of a previous negative experience, and my first time back today, was treated to the same thing again.  I walked out and got a sandwich elsewhere.  I'm done with this place.
author: xxxx x.

description:
I've been a long time customer (about 7 years now) of Mexico au Parc thanks to the delicious burritos and friendly/fast customer service. If you work in the South Park area or really anywhere near the ballpark, this is hands down the best taqueria you'll find. Even if you show up after 12/12:30PM when the lines are long, the service is quite fast. My personal favorite is their "Azteca Burrito," which is what they call their wet burrito; the combination of enchilada sauce, guacamole, and sour cream are stellar and the create a depth of flavor that sets this apart from most other one-dimensional burritos from other taquerias. 

BEST lunch burrito in the area, hands down.
author: Phillip K.

description:
If you are looking for the best Calorie per $$ ratio in South Park/SOMA this is the place to go. Its dependable, fast and fresh. My go to is a super burrito bowl or the tostada. Those run you about $7-8 depending on what you add on. 

Their minimum for cards is something like $8.50 and works out if you go the super burrito route, if not just get a soda or a side of something. Ask for free chips!!!
author: Jethro P.

description: Firt timer to Mexico au parc. My firt inpresion little place big ass line.   Aztecs burrito Is killer.
author: Adrian N.

description:
This is the best Mexican food in the neighborhood. Hands down. I live here, and I've tried them all. 

For breakfast burritos I recommend adding sour cream and pico, and it's heaven. 

Their salsa bar is better than most. 

Their staff are really really sweet. I come in regularly and once the guy forgot to charge me for the add ons, he said no problem if I pay next time, and I did. 

Highest recommendation. Don't be deterred by a long line (out the door), it moves fast!
author: Monica G.

description:
My go to spot in South Park for burritos.  They are only open for a short window around lunch time and the line is usually out the door - but dont let that discourage you.  No matter what the line moves fast.  Step into the left and you hit the counter - burritos and plates.  skip the line and head straight back to the grill (there is never a line here) - order fresh tacos and quesadillas, meats grilled on the spot.  i come here at least 1x/week and the average wait time is 5-8 minutes. $8.00 minimum for credit cards and there is seating for ~20 people inside.  grab one by the window: interior seating gets contested with people waiting in line.  I dont like staring at ass when i am trying to eat....

large selection of meats, plenty of lunch options, something for everyone.

when the sun is out, head across the alley and grab a seat on the lawn or picnic table - mid day picnic's are awesome.
author: Ben C.

description: Got food poisoning from a burrito bowl from this place. It's a shame since it's one of the only cheap options in the area, but the sanitary conditions are just not there. Believe the other bad reviews. I really wanted to like this place, but it nearly sent me to the hospital.
author: Nonada R.

description: I ordered aztecra burrtio and I was waiting for the order. There was few customers got orders passed me. I don't understand why workers were more care other customers than me. They showed me that I'm not matter because I am deaf. They treated me like I'm not customer value. They don't even started to make my order. I decided to leave them
author: Joey D.

description:
Get the Shrimp Quesadilla!

You won't regret it. 

My dining companion didn't, and then longingly looked on as I dug into my cheesy, gooey quesadilla filled with juicy shrimp and sour cream. 

I didn't even need the guacamole (for which they charge extra) because they have a salsa bar with so much from which to choose.

Plus they give you chips on the side (squeeze lime on them -- I learned that when I was in Puebla -- it gives them great flavor)

*Tip: If you're going to order a quesadilla, you need to know the proper procedure!

Step #1: Go to the back grill, cutting past the people waiting out the door in line for burritos and other items.

Step #2: Wait until the order cook is free to take your order.

Step #3: Take the order slip you receive from the cook to the register, where they'll ring you up and take your name.

Step #4: Grab a table and a fork and knife if you're dining in (believe me, you'll need it) and wait. Don't loiter by the cash registers because there's always a huge lunch crowd.

Step #5: Pick up your order when your name is called. Remember the chips!

Enjoy!
author: Diana V.

description: Stepped into this restaurant because it looked appealing from outside for a quick meal. Burritos were not good at all though. I would only give it 2 stars because the salsa Bar was very nice. But otherwise nothing good :(
author: Jigesha D.

description:
Parc place.

Coveted Monopoly card: http://monopoly.wikia.com/wiki/Park_Place

Coveted Mexican cuisine:

- Tortas big enough for two meals and filled with juicy, mild chunks of almost shredded chicken, lettuce, beans and salsa packed between thin, flavor soaked borillo bread.

- Burritos with large grilled tofu squares brought to delicious life with ranchero sauce, black beans and salsa in a wheat tortilla.

- Omelettes with the perfect mix of egg whites (thank you!), homemade potatoes (kindly swapped for rice and beans), onions, tomatoes and bell peppers.

Everything was $5 - $7 and includes sour cream, avocado and cheese if you'd like.

Consider it highly valued culinary property.
author: Jason B.

description: Eh I got a steak quesadilla. Pretty cheap and fast, but the quesadilla was dry, at least they gave free sauce. I miss San Diego Mexican food.
author: Sean W.

description:
Its one of my top 2 burritos in The City.  

El farolito makes the best dinner burrito, but this place makes the best lunch burrito IMHO.
author: Val S.

description: Best veggie burrito thus far in San Francisco, highly recommend! Five stars all the way
author: Fillmoe P.

description: This is the best quesadilla in SF. Tacos are ok, burritos are totally decent. But Quesa Freakin Dilla -
author: Ian M.

description:
I have a love hate relationship with this place as I live right across the street.  I adore their broccoli burrito.

However, the hours they keep make it completely useless to me and anyone else who lives there.  8-4 Monday thru Friday means they only serve people who don't actually live in the neighborhood.  I've stopped coming here not out of principle, but sheer lack of hours available to make it said restaurant.  Do the owners realize that people live in the neighborhood and would like to buy their food?  whatever.  They simply won't get any money from me because they are not open when I can be there to buy stuff.  Their loss.
author: Luci S.

description:
I've gotten the caesar salad from here twice.  My first experience was four stars and the second was so bad that it inspired me to write my first review in over two years.  

If you order the caesar, ask for LIGHT dressing.  I watched the guy making it pour 3 full ladles of caesar dressing on it.  "Too much of a good thing" absolutely applies to caesar salads and I ended up throwing the salad away after a couple bites.  

If this salad were in a Roman senate, I'd pull a Brutus and stab it 23 times to save the rest of the city from it's terribleness.  Lettuce shouldn't be swimming in a pool of dressing.  I didn't order a bottle of dressing and some lettuce.  Maybe the guy who made it has never eaten a caesar salad.  That's the only explanation I could come up with for how awful that salad was.

Now I'm still hungry for lunch and out $8.  Doesn't help that the chips they gave me with the salad were tasteless and stale.  I'll go back to try the burrito, but these guys are on a short leash after this fiasco.
author: Zak K.

description:
I've been patronizing this place for almost two years now, and I must say I've enjoyed each visit.  Here are some of the things I really like about Mexico Au Parc: the food is delicious, the serving portions are good, the service is good, the location is beautiful (adjacent to it is a nice park), and the price is reasonable, considering it's nestled in between the financial district and the Giant's stadium.

I would much rather prefer to have my Mexican fix at Mexico au Parc than national chains like Chipotle since the food here tastes better, and I really appreciate the courteous people serving here. For these several reasons, I highly recommend this place!
author: Kahlil G.

description:
Chicken and Mushroom Quesadilla with everything on it. Remember to get the chips (free) and the hot sauce from the hot sauce bar. I don't remember which sauce was better so I always grab all of them
It is cut in 4 pieces and can feed you for lunch and dinner. Or share it with a co-worker!
$9.50 for lunch, not bad for downtown San Francisco.
author: PreciousSwt P.

description:
Nice staff, good service, great salsa bar. Breakfast burrito was delicious. Would love to try their other offerings.

Cute location across from the park.
author: N L.

description: I went here for lunch today with some co-workers and I've been here a few times and every time it seems to be a pretty decent. I had the chicken burrito Azteca style which is when it is drenched in sauce and covered with cheese, sour cream, guac and salsa. They offer a free bag of chips with the order all for around $9 not too bad and the taste is pretty good not the best burrito ever but certainly not the worst. One of the drawbacks is if you come at the wrong time you could be waiting a while and I also recommend bringing your own drink as they are a little $teep here.
author: Javier A.

description:
Ya, if you wanna be sober and throw up...

I should not be upset at anyone but myself for eating here so many times and expecting  different results. 

Across the board it's a C- on a good day. 

Tortillas are too big. I never feel like there is not enough in them but there is always a fat knot of tortilla that is super gross and runs the length of the "burrito". They don't need more filling, just smaller tortillas. 

The rice - is flavorless, mooshy, and the color of Kraft Mac and cheese... Why do you dump a bag a frozen peas in every batch? It makes it even worse. 

Meat - Carne is tough and gristly, chicken is chicken not screwing this up is no reason for praise congratulations you can probably breathe and walk at the same time, carnitas are fatty and greasy even by carnitas standards. Mole - canned Costco chicken with cinnamon and Hershey's syrup anyone?

Beans - it's a grab bag no matter the kind you select. I promise you they will be over or under cooked and a ton of bean water will make it into your already depressing burrito. 

Chips - out of a bag and stale 75% of the time. 

Salsa - generic and teetering on disappointing. 

Sad part is I've been dumb enough to keep going back and try everything hoping it would get better.... It didn't. 

Don't do it if your new. The line out the door proves people that work in southpark are dumb and or lazy. There are better burritos within spitting distance (do your own research I don't need longer lines)
author: John D.

description: Been here many times, for lunch and breakfast. Great prices, good quality, busy ambiance yet able to relax if you wish for a table experience - or quick take out. There are three menus and stations; one for traditional tostadas, tacos, burritos and chile relllenos (etc), another for grilled items like fresh seafood quesadillas, and another for the breakfast menu.  All are good, and there is a good selection of bottled drinks and also several drinks at the register (such as fresh lime, horchata or jamaica). The salsa bar features up to five or six different types, with small containers for table or take out. Gets busy about lunch (11:30 to 1) because of the little start-ups all around the park area, but often tables are available because they do a lot of take out meals for lunch. So don't be discouraged by a line out the door - it moves quickly !  Usually the park across the street is great for eating your food, but it is currently being renovated. Overall, the experience and food are good enough to keep us coming back. And, if you get a burrito to eat there, ask for it "mojito" (wet) - it'll be drowned in a sauce, with guacamole, sour cream and salsa - Mexican colors for a Mexican meal !  Enjoy . . . .
author: Mark K.

description:
South Park is a tiny neighborhood I hadn't visited yet...this is one of a several cafes on the loop. Solid burrito/taqueria, prices on the high side, portions were good. Decor is very basic, there's a "family style" table that'll accommodate singles or up to 8. Salsa bar.

Know the burritos before ordering; my son ordered a "regular" burrito, and was asked if he wanted sour cream, guac (said yes) and at the register we were charged for a "super" burrito. He liked his burrito but it was so juicy it kinda self-destructed while he was eating it. 

My chicken verde was good, salsa bar had a nice hot salsa (I find that many don't), if you're in the neighborhood it's worth a go.
author: John H.

description:
Delicious solid comfort food! Never disappoint. Line will get long during lunch. Plan to be here earlier or later than normal rush hours. Oh they provides water too, cups on the counter by cashier, and water tank kinda hidden behind the salsa bar.

Bonus: complimentary tortilla chips and self serve salsa bar!
author: YY M.

description:
My favorite Mexican food place in SOMA! Whenever I want to reward myself eating salads all week, I go to this place and get myself a quesadilla with the works - guac and sour cream. It is SO worth it! The quesadillas are huge, so I only finish half for lunch and eat the rest for my before dinner snack. It's even better the second time around! 

My coworkers also go crazy for this place. There's always a long line - one for grilled items (like my quesadilla) and another for the bar - burritos, plates, etc. I've had the burrito once and thought it was pretty good, but just not comparable to the quesadilla.

The people running the place are extremely nice - always a plus to support people who deserve it. ;)
author: Mimi V.

description: Came her for lunch before the rush (around 11). I wanted to try the chicken mole but had the chicken quesadilla instead. I wasn't dissappointed. The tortilla was crispy, chicken was juicy and the guacamole creamy. The staff was very pleasant also. I had the flan with my meal. It was ok I wouldn't order it again. It hit a sweet then bitter flavor for me.Overall, I would come again before the rush to join the atmosphere, food, and view of the park from the window.
author: Dominique G.

description: A perfect place for Mexican food. One fine afternoon found this place for lunch & it didn't disappoint me. A very efficient & cheerful staff serves you one of the best Mexican food in the area. Don't forget to try their wide variety of flavorful salsas, just love them.
author: Vipul Z.

description: decent burritos, good location. Nice staff. Great salsa. Price is what's expected in the area, bout $10 a burrito. Nothing really stands out about the food but the overall experience is super chill and communal, that itself deserves a good rating. It gets busy during lunch as most places would but the lines move fast because, well, they're burritos.
author: Elton F.

description:
Decent inexpensive burritos

Currently, I am a budget traveller so this place was upto the mark for the price. It's in a quite and good neighborhood as well.
author: Shiv C.

description:
4.5 STARS.  Vegetarian and Fan #2!

Being a transplant from the East Coast means that I am constantly blown away by San Francisco's quality taco and burrito utopia.  But this little, wonderfully-warmly-decorated spot has a special place in my heart now - as do its Broccoli (and cheese) Burritos.  Hit them up with some tortilla chips and a selection of salsas from the complimentary salsa bar, and you're in veggie heaven.
author: Yekaterina M.

description: I've eaten here for lunch twice. The burritos are really tasty and really fast. Would have given it more stars but had a very slow experience with my girlfriend when she ordered fish tacos from the grill. It's a little nitpicky, and maybe it was an off day but getting a burrito wrapped up and paid for in 5 minutes and then sitting around for another 15-20 for tacos thew off the stars. Seems like they could improve their queue a bit and make the experience better.
author: Jon R.

description:
Ever since my relatives moved out of South Park, I haven't got a chance to visit the park in a while. It was lunch time and tacos sounded good at that time. Luckily this place was nearby and so I ordered their Azteca taco. Ordering food here during lunch hours is quite complicated. It's crowded, paying for your meal seemed impossible, and picking up your meal took long. (This was on a Tuesday afternoon)

The tacos were good. But it's not worth $4.00 for 1. They could've gave me 2 for the price and long wait. Although i love how they have open salsa bar, that's for the 3rd star..but then again they were very limited giving out their complimentary salsa chips (dine-in only). 

I would like to try their bowls (burrito?) was not sure what exactly they call it but they look really good. TO GO this time.
author: Maria S.

description:
My experience here is entirely my fault because I grew up to be ignorant of Mexican food.

I came here for lunch, because I was craving for a big ass burrito. The top of their menu had 'Azteca Burrito', which had a long list of ingredients (meat, sauce, vege, beans, etc). It sounded cultural too, so I eagerly ordered it.

They asked me what meat I'd like and I said chicken. As expected, they put chicken in there. From this point on, everything became a cultural shock.

Right after they put the chicken in, they wrapped up the burrito. I did not have time to protest, I was surprised because they didn't put in any sauce, onions, lettuce, or anything else that was promised in the 'Azteca Burrito'. By the time I came around to it, the burrito was in the oven. My co-worker was right next to me so I played it cool and didn't make a sound, but in my head I was thinking "wtf?"

As if they read my mind, they took out my tiny burrito, scooped up a spoonful of red sauce, and I watched in horror as they poured it ALL OVER my burrito. WTF!? At this point,
I was in complete shock. I pictured myself grabbing that liquid burrito in my hands, dripping 
 with sauce, eating and smiling with complete disregard of civility. Not Today. I watched in disbelief as they proceeded to put avocados and other sauces on top of  the burrito and at this point it looked like a mush of everything. You could barely see the burrito at this point. My knees were wobbly. 

I was quiet the whole time because I had an internal struggle to keep myself together. Usually when I order food I would make a lame comment about the weather, art, or whatever. But this time I was completely quiet.

Eventually, I figured out that I should be eating the burrito with a knife and a spoon, and that is what I did. It was decent, but I still wished I had a normal burrito instead. I want the good 'ol burrito that I am used to. ( They call it the Super burrito )

I also ordered Horchata drink (it looks white and creamy) because my coworker said it's amazing and tastes like melted churros. I like Churros, but not the drink. 
Liking churros != liking Horchata. 

Horchata tastes like melted cinnamon + mint + sugar, and has a soft-rough texture. I think it's suitable for people with an intense personality, but I'm just an introverty mellow guy.

I gave this place a 4 star for giving me an intense cultural experience.
author: Song Z.

description:
I had to get the sope after they'd run out last time. Luckily I got the very last one! However I realized this also means I got that last shell that mustve been sitting on the display all morning.

Sope
- Cute but I realized this was basically a mini tostada. The sope itself should be softer, more bread-y. This was kind of stale and crunchy. 
- Chicken was pretty good: tender, flavorful, juicy.

Veggie tostada 
- Pretty good fried shell, though maybe a little too crispy (hard to eat with a fork).
- Good deal ($5.50 for veggie) - they give you extra beans for veggie, and as with everything you get tons of sour cream, guac, and lettuce =).
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Disappointing breakfast burritos.  There was a ton of extra tortilla flapping around and after I was done, I realized I had ordered chorizo and egg - and couldn't remember tasting any chorizo.  I did find one very random green pea.

I split a super nachos and arroz con leche rice pudding for a late lunch with a friend. If you ask for less chips, it feels like they also give less toppings so be clear on what you want. 

Anywhere else, it would probably be a 2.5 to 3 stars place for Mexican food on Yelp.

$8 minimum for credit card charges which is enforced.  Oddly, taxes on the breakfast burrito brought it to $5.97 so I paid cash.  The super nachos were priced at $7.75 so you'd think tax would bring it over $8 - but they still waved the minimum sign at us so we paid cash.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I had a fish taco the other day and got some free chips. The tortilla is a bit soggy and too floury to my likings. I ate the things inside but not the tortilla. As for the chips, it was stale. But on the bright side, prices are very cheap. Perhaps I'm expecting too much.
author: Biyin Y.

description:
Super adorbs little mexican joint in the middle of South Park. There's always a line stretching out the door, but the wait is worth it. There are two lines, so pay attention when entering. The line on the right is for all the regular foods and the one straight back is for grilled items.

The sucky part is the min. required for credit card purchasing, but other than that, the food is good. The messy area is the salsa stand next to the register. Maybe they should move it closer to the door. A couple times people were getting their salsa and managed to spill on patrons standing near the counter.

Definitely a great place to try out and fill up.
author: Theresa N.

description:
First time I came here... I ended up on the "other" line (designated for fresh grilled orders) and so I paid a lot more than my coworkers.

Today, I stayed on the right line. 

I ordered a regular burrito + grilled chicken + black beans + cheese. 

Total: $7+ with a handful of chips

I think I'm sold. This place is better than Maya's (for some reason, Maya is uber stingy with chips ~ no clue why? Even if its just right across my work...)

PS: there was a new restaurant across from 21st so there was nobody in this place... we'll see how long that last!
author: Cath M.

description: Nothing particularly special here, but the food is fast and the location is convenient for me since it's in the 'hood (the mean mean streets of south park, you know?).  You get free chips so you can go to town at their salsa bar.  The staff was friendly.
author: Janet Z.

description: This review is for their take out order.  When I walked here, their grill broke unfortunately that morning (things happen).  The guy was very apologetic that i couldn't get my breakfast burrito, but somehow still managed to get me a quesadilla (I was planning on making my own breakfast taco at home).  Unlike a lot of other places I've been to, the quesadilla was made perfectly and was still good when I got home.  Meaning... it was not overly greasy but had just enough cheese.  They also filed wrapped y other tacos to keep it warm.  I'll definitely come back!
author: Stephanie C.

description: I like the Mexican food here.. super veggie burrito, aztec veggie burritos, and the mushroom quessedia's are good here...
author: Avtar V.

description: I've eaten lunch at Mexico au Parc several times and it's been consistently tasty!  They have an assembly line and a grill, so you can choose between large plates, tacos, burritos, and delicious quesadillas (which I recommend).   Prices are reasonable and the salsa bar seems fresh.  Definitely recommend if you work near South Park.
author: Bud L.

description: Really great burritos! I always get the super burrito and I'm never disappointed. I also really like how the gentleman who rings you up always has a smile. Love this place.
author: Savvy P.

description:
Update to my last review - ugh, this is the first time I abandoned my meal mid way after finding not 1, not 2 but 3 chunks of all fatty bits in my chicken mole, I'm done!  Besides the sope was blend and tasteless.  Will be a while before I go back :(

The al pastor was as good as I remember it from years back.  Served nice & hot from the grill, just missing the onion & parsley toppings.  Cochinita pibil was good too, very tender & tasty meat.  Will try chile relleno & chicken mole next...hard to venture out when I keep going back to my favorite al pastor but everyone seems to rave about them so look forward to trying something 'new' :)

Don't expect service w/ a smile...they know they're good, period.  You go for the food any way, not the tiny dingy serving of chips.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Came here again for lunch today, and put to use my prior knowledge of the strange nuances that go along with eating here. I ordered from the register OPPOSITE the entrance (i.e. the one with fresh-grilled meat), which allowed me to skip the 10-person line of people who didn't know any better. I went for the carne asada quesadilla, my buddy got the al pastor quesadilla.

I hit up the salsa bar, and like before, had to navigate around and say "excuse me" to at least 37 different people. They do have good salsas though; the salsa verde was especially thick and flavorful, and the pico de gallo really was excellent.

Again, the carne asada tasted like it was from an American steakhouse, and again, the al pastor tasted like a Chinese dish.

Not much changed, but I find this place so fascinating that I'm going to give it a fourth star. The quesadilla turned out to be less than $7, and with the excellent salsa bar staring at me from across the room, I felt no need to shell out $1.40 for sour cream and guacamole.
author: Geoff L.

description:
Came here for lunch at least 5 times so far this summer and the only thing I can say is that this place has some of the best Mexican food I've had in SF.

I've gotten the super burrito a couple times and I must say it is much better than most other burritos I've had in the city (although not as good as some places in the Mission) but it's still a great value for the price. 

The quesadillas and enchiladas are also very good and come in big portions. 

Would definitely recommend to anyone looking for a great Mexican place for lunch that won't empty your wallet.
author: Julian M.

description:
I see why it's busy, it's good solid burritos at a reasonable price. There's nothing wrong with it, but it's not mind-blowing good. I think the beans are too healthy -- no lard. It's the kind of place you can go to every day and eat, the price is right and there's plenty of food. 

But as I was eating, I realized it tasted like a La Salsa burrito -- not a true hard-core Mexican burrito. Nothing wrong with that, but nothing worth going out of your way for.
author: Paula N.

description:
When I lived here 20 years ago, you could go to almost ANY Mexican fast-food joint and get a great burrito.  But today, not as much.  What happened to my beloved El Toro, with so many wonderful choices, now "dumbed down"..?  Oh, the economy, I guess.  Have to be honest, I wasn't expecting much coming into Mexico au Parc.  I'm usually only in the South Park area on weekends, when it's closed (right?) and from the outside it looks expensive.  But also I'm not very impressed with the other two South Park restaurants.  I was able to finally stop by this place on a weekday, just before closing, and was happy I did.  Chicken tamale was awesome.  And the taco -- it was a monster they put so much stuff on it.  All delicious, and very impressed.  And the prices - reasonable!  

Now my only problem, however, is that I am a white-meat-chicken snob, and I apologize, I know it's "roll your eyes" time, but I only like that kind of chicken in my Mexican food.  So, I'm frequently disappointed, but it's just a fact of life that a lot of places don't use it -- too expensive?  And this place is no exception, but I certainly can't fault them on that, given the standard.

Yeah, from all the Mexican places I've tried so far, I really do like Mexico au Parc!
author: Merrick W.

description:
Left the meat out of my burrito (after charging extra for f-ing SALSA!)
Guy at the counter (not full service, just a counter) was clearly working beyond his capabilities ...with 2 tables of 2 seated, and maybe 4 to-go orders underway.
I sustained a back injury trying to reach the water, which is behind some furniture, and you have to reach all the way under/through the salsa bar sneeze guard to the opposite side. Clearly they want me to buy a gross sugar drink for their own profit, and do not really understand (care about?) the customer experience.
To be fair, what I received was cheap and pretty good- just not what I ordered. They left out the expensive part and took my money anyway.
author: Erin S.

description:
Who knew such a nice and cheap Mexican joint hidden away in little South Park? I did not know this little pocket of San Francisco existed until today, but I'm loving the fact that it's close to my workplace.

I must warn though, drippy tacos can ruin everything!
DRIPPY TACOS = A NO-NO

Seriously, both my shrimp taco and steak tacos were pissing salsa water. The steak was good and there was a lot on one taco. The shrimp was peeled too. Still, I regret getting hot instead of mild because I was dying from the salsa they put on it. I wish they had not put any on and just let me do it myself since they have a salsa bar.

3 tacos + 2 drinks = about $15

$8 minimum credit card purchase

I will be back for the burritos...
author: Jennifer W.

description: After taking lunch to work everyday, I wanted to treat my self to a lunch that wasn't so 'healthy.' The only major downside to this small gem is the line. It moves rather quickly though, so do not be put off by the wait. My order of super nacho's was received quickly. It was 'aiight', but I did eat the whole lot ; )
author: Jaylena P.

description:
I like. Not real street Mexican flavor I look for, but they deliver a very fresh taste. In the morning I like to order the mushroom burrito, or the ham. I like the salsa they have there too. For lunch or dinner I have only tried the beef burrito, but will come back and try something different. 

I like the location, in South Park, great place to eat outside when weather permits.
author: Nye T.

description:
Literally just finished my meal but eaten hear plenty of times. The burritos are assembly line style... What kinda meat? what kinda beans? Not really my thing, I'm more of a taco truck aficionado. So I order straight from the grill to get the freshest meat possible. 

I wait 30 minutes for my food (a lot longer than any taco truck in the area). The shrimp taco had barely any meat in it and was on a bed of cheap packaged lettuce!? They obviously DON'T know Baja style seafood; I'm looking for nicely seasoned fish,shrimp, fresh cabbage with a cooling white sauce and a dabble of Pico. So don't order anything seafood here. The Al Pastor taco is a little better. The marinade was lemony sweet and you got that grill mark flavor too. Wish there was at least some Pico but all in all they don't skimp on the meat. The tortillas were soggy and fell apart due to the foil wrapping, and it probably was just a bad tortilla. 

The price not so great $3.80 (Shrimp) and $3.00 (Al pastor) for 2 tacos. I could of gotten 4 higher quality varieties of tacos at any of the taco trucks in the area for less than 2 bucks a pop. With 3 people working the assembly line, 1 working the grill, 2 at the register... This is why they probably charge so much. Ive seen 2 dudes alone create better food than all of them combined. It is a joke. 

Ambiance: Long but fast moving line of semi yuppies, Diego Rivera prints everywhere.
Service: Free chips and a salsa bar, Not very fun or happy feeling. 
Food: Try there Al Pastor if your into pork  and a strawberry drink, everything else is pretty mediocre.
Overall Score: 2.4
author: Sean B.

description:
This is my go-to Mexican restaurant. Skip the long line by going directly to the grill and order something from the Grill menu. I really love anything with mushrooms... a burrito or quesadilla are my typical choices.

I also enjoy the tofu ranchero tacos. One taco is pretty much a meal and it's cheap, too!

Everything here is consistently good, fresh and the service is friendly. Their salsas are also excellent. The horchata is very nice and they have Mexican Coke which is a big plus.

Get take-out and enjoy it on a sunny day in the park. C'est magnifique!
author: Tala D.

description: Beware of any Mexican restaurant with a French name. The food is plain tasting. The portions aren't great and most of all it is overpriced. Don't believe me? Pay $1.00 for a side of Guacamole and see what you get.
author: Steven B.

description: These guys have a very unique spin on flavors.  The mains are just plain bland as-they-come, but the condiments are inventive and shockingly good.  It's a great value for the area and is located on one of the last cute streets in soma.  They layout and furniture materials feel like they are designed to make you want to leave, but the nearby park benches are a perfectly nice place to sit and eat.  I really wish either that this was a snack-bar only, OR that they would step up their game with the mains, because I really want to give them a better review than this.
author: Nathan C.

description:
Vegetarian & Fan.

Their tofu is simmered in this amazingly flavorful sauce that just works perfectly. And if you're not into tofu or just feel like being healthy they do this steamed broccoli burrito that is amazing. It's probably $.50 more expensive than it should be, but gosh it's worth it.

Watch out for lines during lunch. But they usually move pretty quickly. Decent salsa bar too.
author: Paul C.

description:
Mexico au Parc is a nice Mexican restaurant to check out if you're in the South Park area, but I wouldn't kill myself trying to get across town to eat there. The service is friendly and the portions are large. The burritos are enormous, and they definitely come with a fork and knife prerequisite. 

The ingredients are fresh and they have *gasp* real classic Coke in the glass bottles in the drink case (Definitely worth at least 1 star for that). It can get pretty busy at lunch, and I wish they would be open for dinner, but I'm still a fan.

If you're eating in the 2nd st/S. Park area, check this place out before throwing your money away somewhere else in the area.
author: Jason H.

description:
This place is decent and convenient. It is nothing to write home about, and I wold never seek this place out if I didn't work literally around the corner, but I am always satisfied after eating here.

Mexico au parc (yes, a Mexican restaurant with a French name, indeed thaat's indicative) has a great location right on South Park in SOMA. Come lunchtime, the place is flooded with the daily mix of techies on a lunch break from their startups (I'm in that group) or art students from the Academy of Art across the street. There's often a long line at lunch, but it moves very quickly for takeout. Sitting inside at peak time can be more stressful.

There's two lines--get in the line to the right. The other line inside is more expensive options. If you want a grab and go meal, which you probably do, get on the right side. Do not expect friendly service--they are trying to get everyone in and out as soon as possible.

The meats look really good and I've been told they are and that the sauces are bomb, but as a vegetarian I get the Tofu Ranchero or the Supper Veggie burritos. Both come to under $6 and I can save half if I'm not totally starving. Note: I ask for hot salsa and these are NOT spicy. Everything here needs more flavor!

Good selection of tortillas--whole wheat I'm a fan of, Spinach is also an option--and they move fast. The burritos I mentioned are satisfying--they are definitely filling--but you are not going to bite into one and think "DAMN that's a good burrito!" You will think "Yay, my stomach is not growling anymore." And that counts for something. They are decent, not great.

When you go to pay they will put a handful of chips in your bag, which is nice. The chips are NOT GOOD. Maybe just because I am a saltaholic but these taste unsalted and kind of taste like nothing. Then you get your own salsa at the bar next to the registers. The red onion/cilantro (at least I think that's what it is!) are bomb. And I haven't tried the aguas frescas yet but they look delicious.

Bottom line: decent food. Great setting. It'll satisfy you. But don't come from far away to go here. Grab a burrito, sit on a park bench, soak up the sun, and all will be well.
author: Courtney A.

description:
Alright, really I might say four stars, but I want to see them get over 3.5 overall. ;)

This place serves one of the best tacos in the city: fresh ingredients, house made salsa,  sizable, and SUPER affordable.  The salsa is a little different every time I go in.

Don't be fooled by the long lunch line from noon to two, they serve at lightning speed.
author: Cassie P.

description: Had a carne asada super burrito with green sauce. They have a really fast take out system so if your in a hurry a great spot to grab and go. Parking is kinda of a issue. Clean area to eat inside or plenty of space in park outside. Great quality food, with decent prices, and  excellent staff. For sure coming back.
author: Michael C.

description: yo queiro mexico au parc! It's not like this is the only place nearby that offers mexcian cuisine, but this is by far one of the best places nearby to get my south of the border fix and can't make the long 15 drive to the mission.  this place is always packed. sometimes the lines are out the door.  the staff are pleasant and the food is delicious! i usually stick with the nachos but i've tried their burritos which are good sizes for the price you pay.  the salsa is always fresh and sometimes a mess but only on busy days. I blame the customers for that! be neat! Their strawberry agua fresca is really good and not too sweet.
author: Zara-Maria S.

description:
I was quite prepared for the madness I experienced here because I read several reviews here first.

Important stuff worth recapping here:

1. Only the cashier speaks English everyone else just makes random gestures, usually to indicate you are in the wrong line. Next time I will use my Spanish to make them feel more at ease.
2. There are two lines: different price points, different amount of time for food prep. Burrito bar is the line to the right, you can only order from the menu over the burrito bar...pay attention!!!
3. The line moves quick, so don't be discouraged.

Stuff tastes good here, but its not mission quality. I wanted more flavor for sure, but sine there aren't too many options in the area, I will probably come back.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
Great Mexican food, especially the Tostada Salad, Burritos, Quesadilla, Nachos, Tacos, I can go on and on... let's just say their food is really delish.

It's totally located in one of the nicest eating spots down SOMA, South Park. I must say that this area of San Francisco looks very much like some place you would see in Europe.

Going back to the food, I am a big fan of their Tostada Salad. They make their own tostada bowl, with all the nifty ingredients you could ask for. I recommend going vegetarian for an order of this nifty meal since it's well worth your money than adding extra 2 bucks for meat. 

By the way meatatarians, you wouldn't even notice that there's no meat on the vegetarian option!

If ever you want to swing by for lunch, go around 11:00am-sh or 1:00pm-ish, the lines are not that long at those times!
author: Pierre B.

description:
The burritos here are okay but I ordered a shrimp fajita burrito from the grill and it took FOREVER. While the burrito tasted fresh, it wasn't worth the 20+ minute wait from the time I ordered. If I go back, I will definitely order from the regular line where you get your burrito made just like Chipotle.

I did like that they had whole wheat tortillas and black beans and I love this area in South Park.
author: Jenna Q.

description:
Mexico au Park is not really different from other Mexican lunch spots in SOMA. The food is ready to go when you come, cafeteria style. It's fast satisfying and yummy but nothing to go nuts about. The location and furnishing of Mexico au Park though is definitely a step up from other places, well lit and at the same time cozy and inviting.

Southpark nearby is another killer Plus. You can have your take out outside on a bench or at a picnic table in the sun. Can't ask for better during your lunch break.  For a hungry stomach I recommend the super burrito with "green" chicken.Credit card limit is $10.00. That is a little annoying as it is more than you usually pay for a single lunch. So bring cash.
author: Sketchbook S.

description: Mexico au Parc was what I thought it would be after checking out the reviews. The line goes out the door and up the block during the 12 o'clock lunch hour, but goes fast, as the staff are super efficient at moving it. They take cards, give you free chips and have a salsa bar. You can get a lot of food for $10, which can be rare for lunch. My chicken mole was okay, it didn't really leave a lasting impression on me. Though if you're vegetarian, this place is a gem- they have a special vegetarian menu that looks really good.
author: K M.

description:
I go to school nearby so went there to pick up lunch. The service was good but with almost no one in the restaurant, it took them a really long time to prepare my order which was a simple Burrito. I don't order Mexican often and apparently I was told that for the price I paid for my Burrito it was way too much.

It cost me 10$ and 15-20 minutes wait for a egg-chorizo-mushroom Burrito. 

The owner was really nice thought me a few words of spanish. 

Might be back some day :)
author: Vickie Z.

description:
I've had the Tofu Ranchero Burrito twice now-- comes with tofu, beans, rice, and salsa. Any extras costs 40cents+. Kinda weird that nothing else was included with the burrito, and i ended up having to douse it with the salsa's from the salsa bar to enhance the taste. 

The second time I chose the spinach tortilla and added cheese to the burrito and it (obviously) tasted much much better.

I'd definitely go back again because it's in such an AMAZING location, with quick, fresh food. When it comes to food, I don't care if its "authentic" or not...as long as it TASTES good. I'd probably go for a quesadilla next. 

appx $9 for burrito & bottle of soda, including free bowl of chips.
author: Kristal N.

description:
I haven't been here in a while, I no longer work nearby and it's a little too far to get there and back during my lunch hour.  Once in a while I make the trek even though it means eating my burrito as I walk back up 2nd Street. :D

Very, very tasty burritos.  I've never had a bad one here.  They're perhaps a little on the pricey side (if you get a super or Azteca) but they are delicious and pretty large.  Everything tastes really fresh.  I like that they have a lot of non-standard options - veggie options beyond just 'bean & cheese' (they have tofu burritos & tacos, and delicious broccoli burritos). *I* am not going to eat a tofu burrito, but it's nice that they offer them. It makes it an easy choice when I'm going to lunch with vegetarians.  I could go on - they just have a much more interesting selection than your average burrito/taco place.

Who serves the best burrito in SF? I will never get into THAT discussion again... but Mexico au Parc is one of my favorites. :)
author: Heidi M.

description: A little taqueria hidden in South Park that is good for a quick meal. Menu is pretty simple with the usual meats and mediums (taco, burrito, quesadilla, torta, etc.). All-in-all it is what you can expect from any typical Mexican joint and nothing really stood out. Be clear and concise when you order because they may screw up the order if not.
author: Ed L.

description: This place is not mexican at all (said by a mexican) and the food is kinda junkie texmex so you better try somewhere else. Owners, if you are mexicans please honor our ancestors and serve real mexican food.
author: Alberto X.

description:
Best $5 lunch in the South Park area.  Five bucks buys you a regular burrito with your choice of meat (or a veggie one for less) and a trip to their famous salsa bar.  And free chips.  It's a very filling meal.

Their grilled chicken tastes nicely charred.  Just right.  The tinga chicken makes your burrito too wet and messy.  The carnitas are really, really good.  I also recommend the wet burritos.  They use high quality ingredients and give you lots of choices (pinto, black or refried beans? spinach, regular, or whole wheat tortilla?)

DO NOT miss the salsa.  They make the best salsa in town and if you put tons of it on your food, everything you eat there will taste really, really good.

I haven't tried them for breakfast yet but it's nice to know that they have that option.  

Bummed that they aren't open on weekends...or for dinner.

Other tips:  Get there early on weekdays to beat the lunch crowd. Parking can definitely be an issue too, particularly around lunch time.

The more burritos I eat, the more I miss Mexico Au Parc's burritos.  They have the best grilled chicken and salsa.  It's the only Mexican eatery I've purchased salsa from.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I wouldn't recommend coming here in morning for the breakfast burritos.  You don't get the bang for your 5 bucks, and the chorizo tasted re-heated from the previous day. 

Both the super and the azteca (wet) burrito cost the same.  I love the red sauce for the azteca burrito.  Lines move quickly during the lunch rush.  Added bonus is they don't have those cheap flimsly forks, I mean I know its plastic forks but they have the more durable ones for take-out!
author: David C.

description: Some of the best, fast mexican burrito food you can get.
author: Tedd F.

description:
Once of the best Mexican food in the area. Loved their Tostada Salad and Chile Releno. Even their Chips and Salsa sauces are great. My office was right opposite the park so this was my regular lunch spot. It gets little busy during peak lunch time, but worth waiting a few minutes. The seting is nice in the Park and prices are very reasonable. The staff is great and very friendly. I wish they were open for dinner too, but they close early. 
Its unfortunate that my office was shifted to another city. But even now, I never miss a chance to go there if I am in that area.
author: Abhi T.

description: My favorite burritos in SoMa! Plus, they have  wider variety of Mexican than your normal taqueria. What could be better than enjoying a tasty burrito in South Park on a sunny day? Often a long line during lunch but it moves quickly. They have a great salsa bar here ... I recommend either the green and the hot salsa. Thankfully, their hot salsa isn't a wimpy hot.
author: Tom F.

description: Good, cheap, quick Mexican food. I usually have leftovers.
author: Heather R.

description: Super cheap and delicious lunch!  Lots of vegetarian options, even refried beans!  It gets pretty busy at lunch time, but the service is fast.
author: Christina G.

description: Finally got a chance to eat here. I got the Super Nachos, no beans, shredded pork in a mild red sauce. I asked the guy what it was called but I was unable to understand him so after the 3rd time I gave up. Their hottest sauce was not hot at all. It had good flavor to it though. I wish there was more heat to these dishes but I like my food super spicy. Their salsa bar is chill. I usually dump and ton of Pico De Galo, cilantro, onions, and hot salsa on top. The meat was really tasty so over nachos was good. A little pricier than the usual taquerias I visit but its SOMA... If i am craving mexican that I will here again.
author: William K.

description: Mole is good. Ask for chips, but watch out for entitled SOMA startup jackasses at the salsa bar. They will shove you out of the way because their time is more important than you (fact).
author: Phuong M.

description:
Okay, I've been won over. I maintain that they aren't the best in the entire world, but sunny lunches in the park make this a great workday option!

I get the tacos or sopas, which look pretty small, but when you get down to business, they really fill you up.  And for under $5, that's a pretty reasonable deal.  I hear that the prices on burritos went up, but whatever.  You don't need to eat 5 lbs of beans and rice anyway. Don't be greedy. Did you know that a it takes about 8,000 lbs of fresh seafood a day to keep the blue whale well fed?
author: Mari C.

description:
I've had lunch here a few times and loved it each time. Its not extremely impressive but its good Mexican food at a okay price. I've had a burrito, tacos and tostada. All were great but the shrimp tacos seem to be over priced but at least they taste good. 

The only downfall to Mexico Au Parc is that lunch time is a hassle but hey what can you do? There are a bunch of little businesses in the area and they got to eat too! So when its busy you might be looking at a 10 to 15 minute wait plus the extra wait if you order from the grill. Ordering from the grill is worth the wait. 

If you're in the SOMA / South Park area go try it out!
author: Karim R.

description:
The Aztec Burrito is amazing and the steak quesadilla is a close second. But they do not blow you away with mexican awesomeness. You have to factor in the price to quality ratio as well, both the burrito and quesadilla mentioned above are $9+. 

The wait can be brutal on a weekday around lunch time...just as a heads up.
author: Matt Z.

description:
fast and efficient without sacrificing freshness.

That's one of my regular lunch place.
author: Yann K.

description:
Fail.

So this joint makes a big point about it's "fresh grill." Okay, I'm game I thought. On my first (and last) visit today I walked in, past the stream tray "assembly line of burrito sadness," and proceeded to the aforementioned grill. I ordered three tacos (one al pastor, one chorizo, and one basic chicken). The total with a bottle of water was $12. Weak, but what the hell, this is South Park, and I have a job. Good ten minute wait. Still no problem, it was lunch on a weekday.

THEN things got bad. The person manning the grill had clearly gotten to my order. I saw them pick up a handful of corn tortillas and, wait for it, proceed to put them in the steamer! Shit, shit, shit. Now, I knew I was fucked. A few minutes later, I was handed my order, and I headed for the park to "enjoy" my "tacos."

Goddamnit. Just what I feared. Taco soup. My three tacos where slapped together with a ton of overly watery filling slopping from one side to another. You couldn't tell where one taco started and the other began. And to make matters worse, the steamed tortillas where quickly turning into tortilla mud and threatening whatever structural integrity remained. The chorizo filling was decent, but that one is pretty impossible to screw up. The al pastor was a watery mess. And the chicken "aztec" taco is likely causing millions of long-dead native Americans to roll over their graves.

If you like being sad or you just hate food and excess cash in general, this is the place for you.
author: robert h.

description:
I love Mexican food. 
Seriously.
It is an addiction of sorts and my friends are concerned over my level of attachment for burritos.

This is why Mexico Au Parc was dangerous to have around my work.

Nevermind the sandwiches, Thai, salads,burgers and crepes I had at a stone's throw.

Nope.

I would rather eat a burrito, and for SoMa this place was pretty decent.

Their burritos are HUGE and a little bit pricier than their competition Chavos, but their salsa bar made it worth while.

Cute spot too to sit and enjoy your food, while gazing at people walking by.
author: Kathy K.

description: Man oh man this place gets busy. Luckily I called in my order before getting there. Me and my coworkers tried all their street tacos, delicious! Didn't realize how filling one can be, especially the super tacos. All good!
author: Samantha H.

description:
Ever since I discovered this little place in the middle of South Park, I can't get over it! It's 80 degrees in SoMa and my co-workers and I are figuring out where to eat outdoors... (a light-bulb goes off *ding!*) Mexico au Parc it is! 

Instead of getting a quesadilla this time, I went for something smaller. I got a "Super Taco" with tofu. I was initially going to get two tacos, but the worker recommended I get one since it's super-sized. The super tacos are fat - and I mean FAT. It's as filling as half of a burrito because they stuff beans, lettuce, your choice of meat, sour cream, and a whole lot of yummy-ness in them. 

They also give plenty of chips and you pack your own salsa. They have a small section in the restaurant where you pick and choose which type of sauce you want to go with your order. 

Mexico au Parc, I'll be back for more - lots more.
author: Linda T.

description:
au Parc au yea!  Burritos the size of small infants, I savored every bite. 

Comes with delectable homemade salsas and authentic chips you can't even find in Mexico.   There's like 235425 different types of meat to choose from, which is killer. And they even slap on guacamole for free if you want it.  Nice!

Deliciously large portion sizes. Reasonably priced. And..

Here's the kicker. They have ice-cold Cola-Cola in a bottle. Old school style.  I may have died and gone to Mexico err....Heaven!

au Parc, I will return.   au yea!!
author: Troy C.

description: I like this place. It is unpretentious, the staff is friendly, the food is solid if not spectacular, price and quantity are reasonable, and they have  an open salsa bar and give a small bag of chips with every order. One star extra for providing a dependable eating option in this part of town. It gets very busy with people standing in line outside the store on the sidewalk. You can beat the line if you go there a little early.
author: kumar k.

description: Their ham breakfast burrito is good, and extremely filling. The regular/super burritos are okay. Nothing in comparison to places n the Mission, but it eats the job done. The salsa bar is great. 3.5 stars, but I'll round up to 4 since I like their salsas.
author: Eduardo R.

description: Pretty decent Mexican place. The tortas here are pretty darn good. I've also had chile relleno, which was also good. Not a bad place to go if you work in the area.
author: Thuan N.

description: Not bad had the Azteca wet burrito it was great. Small and crowed
author: Donald M.

description:
Decent but pricey, not very authentic. Highlights: Steak quesadilla, wet burrito, tostada. Chips are too tough and salsa not great too. Everything is about 20-30% more expensive than it should be. 

I've been going here for years but it's honestly just mediocre and pricey for mexican food. If you want real mexican you gotta go to the Mission. If you don't have that kind of time, this place fits the bill. 

Location is great though, right across the street from South Park so you can lounge in the sun and grass.. but I wouldn't recommend it. There's dog poop everywhere because of a-hole yuppies who don't pick up after their dogs.
author: Brandon O.

description: Bad food poisoning. Same thing happened to my coworker 2 years after it happened to me. Good luck with all that
author: Graham R.

description:
This place is delicious, and the service is great.  I prefer the tacos to the burritos, but everything I've had has been solid.  Fresh and tasty, and hits the midday Mexican-food-craving spot.

To the people complaining about the confusion about the two lines: Really?  It was that hard to figure out?  There are clearly two menus and two different places to order from those two menus.  Think for a moment and quit your bitchin.  And the grill line takes longer because... wait for it... they have to grill your food.  Not just scoop it into a tortilla.

And to the people complaining about the staff's lack of English skills: Seriously?  A) You're incorrect.  B) Regardless, you're in a taqueria, and the staff are really nice and always get the orders right.  What more do you want?

This is an excellent lunch spot if you work anywhere near South Park and like good, fresh Mexican food.
author: Erin G.

description:
Same old story - fast, convenient and reasonably priced so I find myself here alot even though it's not particularly amazing.

I'm a chile relleno burrito with refried beans and spicy salsa kind of girl. I do love chile relleno and the fact that they stuffed it into a tortilla? Brillz.

Plus, these things really are huge and they have Mexican Coke. Just be sure to wipe off the lip after you pop the cap b/c they tend to have a bunch of gross rust around the top.

Anyways, the ladies have always been perfectly nice to me if anything just a little difficult to understand. But I've got the routine down: they ask what you want, what kind of beans, what kind of meat and what kind of salsa. 

A-OK Mexico au Parc. See you tomorrow.
author: Kori S.

description:
I feel like a failure.  It's been over a week.... with nary a new review. Thank god for my friend amanda, who's helping me find new places to eat close enough to work for me.

I showed up in fear... nay in sadness.  I only get 30 mins for lunch, and this place is popping like a prepubesent pimple!  Like splattering on the mirror popping. 

I get in though, and I see how quick the line moves.  Happier than a swedish school girl, I order a delicious carnitas super burrito, get some chips at the register... and voila!  5 minutes later I have a seat and a burrito bigger than my head.

I like the food here, but I mgiht have been more in love with the ambiance.  All the workers are smiley, it's not too loud, and you can sit by a window and look at the highschool kids skateboarding in the streets.... (I try not to wish they'd fall... but I'm only human).  

The burrito was highly above average, thought not the best I've ever had.  TO those people complaining about a price hike... get over it!  Perfectly fair prices given the location and business..  
Sorry your 8 dollar burrito now costs 6 instead of 4... it's still a deal!
author: Joseph F.

description:
Although they can sometimes be disorganized, Shatangi always leaves Mex au Parc with the best burrito.  The service is fast and friendly and there is ample traffic to assure that the food is always the freshest.  Perfectly located.  Bravo a todos!!

Shatangi told you...
author: Njon W.

description:
For 25 cents extra, your burrito can be covered in enchilad sauce, covered with cheese and extra salsa. 

They call it the Aztec burrito. 

Eating the Aztec burrito is sort of like watching the last episode of Lost--yes you knew it was bloated and overdone and you were ok with that. But then it sank in: woah, it also sucked. 

And thats what I feel about this burrito. A lot of little does not add up to, well, a lot. So much cheese, so much sauce, so much meat. Do we really demand this little from a burrito? 

And if so, where do the flavors come in with such a cacophony of ingredients? 

Not here.
author: George J.

description: Yummy tostadas! Their spicy chicken is really good. I just moved offices and miss having this place as my regular option.
author: JS K.

description:
So if you think a place called "Mexico au Parc" will not have authentic Mexican food ... well, then you are correct. 

I can't believe this place is as packed with people as it usually is. I guess the folks who eat here would not know the difference between a Taco Bell chalupa and a burrito from El Farolito unless it was featured in an article in McSweeneys. By the way, that last line was a total slam on hipsters. Sit on it. 

Anyway, if you want real Mexican food in the area, walk a couple blocks to 4th Street and go to Chavo's.
author: Lupe P.
