description: Cheap, delicious mexican food for days when you need to grab a quick bite during lunch hour. It's close to the office right in South Park--no complaints.
author: Patricia Q.

description:
It's not a cheapo burrito joint.  

After dropping off my laptop at the laptop hospital, I decided to take some time to enjoy a neighborhood I haven't seen in 7 months.  South Park was jumping with commerce today!  The economy is alive and well in San Francisco.  People were interviewing at the tables, talking about new job assignments, and phoning me with opportunities.  Yes, phoning, but none of the other diners seemed to mind.  

The steam table looked about normal for a burrito shop.  I ordered 2 super tacos, which turned out to be beans, rice, shredded lettuce, shredded cheese, sour cream, and carne asada piled so high on 4" flour tortillas that I couldn't even see the tortillas.  These, with a real Coke hecho en Mexico, cost $9.75, and I got a free basket of corn chips on the side.  There was also a salsa bar, in case I wanted something on the chips.  I ate the tacos with a fork, because I couldn't pick them up.  

The weather was beautiful, as were the clientele, and it was a pleasure to walk through the park before and after lunch.  The Gran Oriental Filipino Masonic Hall dominated the scene, and apparently had a lot to do with the park's redevelopment and revival -- there were also Gran Oriental Filipino apartments on the north side of the park.  

It would be nice if the 30 and 45 stopped closer to South Park, but I was able to find the offset bus stop "at 3rd and Brannan" without too much trouble.  Hint:  It's closer to Townsend than Brannan; keep looking.
author: David D.

description:
Great place, you'll find the traditional Americanized Mexican food (a.k.a. Burritos, Nachos etc...) and they are actually pretty tasty. 

The place is really nice to go for a lunch break, service is good and friendly. 

I usually always have the "Azteca Burrito" and it's great, quite massive for a tiny price.

The "Aguas Frescas" are a must, Horchata is really good, so try it! 

If you're ever by South Park and want to grab some nice food, give it a try!

$8 credit card minimum, you'll probably spend a bit more for a hearty meal.
author: Javier B.

description: Great salsa bar and burrito. They have super long lines at lunch so prepare yourself. They are also opened for breakfast, I always walk by and it smells so good, If I was more of a breakfast person I would stop by. I wish these guys opened a few hours later (they close at 5pm) then I could grab it for dinner.
author: Kevin K.

description: It's no great shakes, but it's decent enough when I"m in the mood for Mexican while at work.  What IS amazing, though messy, is their salsa bar.  Love the avo-green, and the hot.  The diced onion, cilantro and jalapeno is also really yummy.
author: Tamar D.

description:
This place is genuinely terrible.  They skimp on everything, the meat is dry (obviously made early in the day and left under the heatlamps for hours), the veggies aren't fresh, the lines are long and the employees are rude.  The worst part are the stale tortillas.

I have a feeling the location makes them lazy, as they are smack dab in the middle of South park resulting in the giant lines stretching down the block.  I am pretty sure a joint that only served PB&J in this same location would draw simliar crowds.  Ate here twice and swore to never go near it again.  

They make no effort and they don't deserve your money people!  Walk a couple extra blocks and go to Victor's.
author: Stephen R.

description: A Mexican joint with a French name should be your first red flag. Come here if you a.) like your burritos sloppy and flavorless b.) you fear spice.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Flavorful, authentic Mexican food in a charming urban park oasis. What's not to like?

I had two sopes, a chicken mole and a chicken tinga. Both were topped with meat, beans, salsa, lettuce, guac and cotija cheese, and cost $3.75 apiece. They also have a bunch of other options, from tostadas to burritos. 

A nice little salsa/topping bar on the side and a relaxing atmosphere make for a definite go-to lunch spot.
author: David Z.

description:
I've eaten lunch here: it's Americanized Mexican food. Had a burrito. Certainly nothing wrong with it. I like to have this sort of stuff from time to time. It's a good value, very quick service, it's tasty and you can't complain about the portion sizes.

Note: it can be a bit hard to get a table during lunch, if you're with more than 2 or 3 people. It can be even harder if people with room to share, refuse to share.

There are entire picnic tables (complete with benches) in the dining area. When the place gets crowded, more than one group might have to sit at a single table.  But on my visit, a single person was possessed to sit at one of these picnic-style tables and copped an attitude when asked if the 4 of us could sit at the other side of the table.

It was sorta fun to watch the expression on his face after he snarled at us that "I'm sitting here!" and the 4 of us sat down anyway. Even though there was still enough room at that table for 4 more people, he scarfed down the remainder of his food, slamming down his fork after each bite and slamming down the bottle of tea after each swig.

Each time he did this, the group of us snickered. So he'd slam them down even harder. More snickering. Snowball effect. Mocking the douchebag became almost like a sport.

After the douche dramatically stormed out, another person asked if he could sit at the table. "Sure, go ahead."  And we finished the meal in peace. Amazing how much farther you get in life when you're not a prick to others.

Of course, our interaction with he-who-never-gets-laid isn't influencing my review of this eatery; it just made it a bit more memorable. Hopefully, doucheboy got his badly-needed diaper change.
author: Tim B.

description:
I love me a good burrito.

I especially love a good burrito that is affordable and within walking distance (for me, that is like one city block). Mexico Au Parc is my go to burrito store in SOMA. One negative: a line out the door during peak lunch times. It usually moves pretty quickly, but it's never that fun to wait. I recommend the breakfast burritos; my fave is the mushroom! Add some cheese and some spicy salsa and I'm set for the day!

Another super deal is the super taco with your choice of meat...with some chips and salsa it's plenty to fill you up for lunch for less than $5!
author: Sylvia H.

description:
This is a great spot to grab some lunch if you work in the area. For me the quesadilla is the way to go. Gotta love a hot, gooey cheese filled chicken quesadilla.  The aqua frescas are always really good too.

Only real downside is that there is usually quite a line, but that is the sign of good food I think.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Probably the closest thing to a mission burrito you're going to find in this neighborhood. Mexico au Parc does not make outstanding burritos, but they do satisfy that burrito crazy much better than anyone else in the hood. That being said, it's also nice to be able to grab your burrito and go enjoy it in the park. 

It's cheap, it's close, and it's got a decent salsa bar.
author: Allyson S.

description:
Not impressed with the burrito (I'm too spoiled with Mission burritos!). I've made my way exactly once since my work relocated to SOMA. I'm a firm believer burritos should be good without salsa or hot sauce. Mine was pretty bland. I didn't have time to get the sauce. I'm sure I'll be back as a regular since this is the only Mexican in the area, but I love that it's in the middle of South Park.

What should I try next time?
author: Jeanne C.

description:
When I've eaten too much Japanese food, I get cravings for Mexican food (don't know why).   In those occasions, Pancho Villa Taquiera -- my idea of fast, cheap, basic, and yummy Mexican food -- used to be the fix.   

Today, I had lunch at Mexico au Parc, and it has replaced Pancho permanently.  I immediately liked it when I saw choices of meat -- beef, chicken and pork.  They were chunky and dry (i.e. not drenched in sauce).   I followed most other people and got their burrito.  They melted the cheese on top with sour cream, guacamole, salsa and some sauce.  It was so delicious.  

But why are they NOT open for dinner and weekend?  When I am supposed to enjoy your cheap beer and wine, unless I change my policy of staying sober during weekday daytime?   What I'm supposed to do after a big Japanese dinner on Friday night?
author: Mami T.

description: I had a craving for a burrito, and was certainly not disappointed buy the taste, size, price, and fillings at this cute little place in South Park. I ordered the super veggie fajita burrito w/ a wheat tortilla. It was huge, and stuffed with tons of grilled veggies! They also gave me plenty of chips and the salsas were tasty too. This is definitely a winner among the other mexican restaurants I've tried in this hood. I guess I found my new burrito lunch spot! Yay!
author: Sonya D.

description:
The taco line is a feast for the eyes for a hungry hungry hippo such as myself.  Your dream feast can be built with any combination of meat (in many varieties of sauces), veggies, beans, anything that you desire, really, and yea...that s*& was good.

I have been craving their carnitas ever since I ate here with the bf and my friend/realtor extraordinaire Claire to sign paperwork and scarf down some lunch.  My chicken mole taco was also quite good, and love the free little basket of chips and salsa bar.  Claire mentioned that the seating can be a bit tough during the lunch hour rush, but we managed to easily snag an end of one of the picnic style tables.

A definite must if you're in the area and need some delicious, fresh, and inexpensive sustenance.
author: Tanya N.

description:
I know I shouldn't expect too much from a burrito joint in SOMA, but when I saw this 4 star rating I was pretty excited, I was definitely left underwhelmed though.  

Everything was OK but nothing was really great.  I had the Tostada Bowl with Carnitas.  The meat was tender but it was somewhat lacking in flavor, as was the guacamole.  The Tostada bowl however was a delicious...it was a giant fried flour tortilla, and boy was it greasy and tasty.  I think that my Boyfriend's burrito was the better choice, although it too was somewhat lacking in flavor.  

The best part is that this place is located right next to the park which is the perfect place to take a load off and eat lunch.  It's definitely no El Farolito, but for SOMA it's pretty damn good.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Just devoured a Mexico Au Parc burrito for lunch, so I figured that my ridiculous food coma would allow me to write the best review...

After waiting in a long line (it was out the door!) I was ready for some serious Mexican food action. I tend to stick to the super burrito, which includes guac, sour cream and cheese in addition to meat, rice, beans and salsa. 

The ingredients are very fresh and I love that they melt the cheese directly onto the tortilla. Don't forget to hit up the salsa bar on the way out! It will take you a while to fill up enough of those teeny little containers with pico de gallo to cover your enormous burrito. 

They accept credit cards but ask for an $8 minimum.
author: lindsay w.

description:
Very nice place in South Park. Many of the folks here also work at La Fonda in the Inner Sunset. Never made the connection until now... duh!

PROS:
1. The food is actually really tasty, fresh and not greasy
2. Serving sizes are just right
3. They don't over cheese everything 
4. The staff are very friendly and the line moves really quickly even during peak lunch hour times
5. My company has ordered many a staff lunches from here and no complaints, only compliments
6. Reasonably priced
7. Grab your food and find a nice spot in South Park to watch dogs walk around and grown ups swing on swings
8. GOOD salsa!

CONS:
1. The line can just get a bit frustrating if you're in a hurry

All in all, a great place, good food, good service and definitely a place I go to often.
author: Amit S.

description: Like this place a lot, tastes great and fresh. Good customer service, clean and location is nice and quiet part of the city.
author: Fashionista M.

description:
The grilled mushroom burrito is the best!  Even hardcore carnivores would be impressed with it.

Awesome salsa bar, too, but beware -- the ladies who work there will slit your throat if they see you making a salsa parfait, which is what I like to do:  pico de gallo, chopped onions and jalapenos, cilantro, and different salsas layered together in one of the plastic water cups, because the tiny ones for salsa are just. too. small.  I like a lot of salsa with my burrito.  

Actually, now that I'm writing about it, I'm gonna have to take off a star (from five down to four), because one time on a friday afternoon (read:  three o'clock, lunch rush is over, no more customers, getting ready to close for the weekend), I went in to pick up a phone order and the counter bitch told me I couldn't have more than two tiny containers of salsa, and even went so far as to come over and take the near-empty bowls away from the salsa bar.  Wtf??

I tried to boycott after that, but every once in a while, the mushroom burrito still convinces me to stop by.  The chile relleno burrito is an interesting concept, too.
author: daphne w.

description:
People in my office are way more fans of Maya, but I like Mexico au Parc's al pastor burritos.  They don't mess with that pineapple business, authenticity be darned.  At $8+ for a super burrito, it sets you back a little more than Maya's, but it's just a different feeling altogether.

Service is friendly and quick, the burrito is made right in front of you on the grill, and they have a lot of options that they will tailor to you.  I will say that their chips leave a little to be desired, but their salsas do not.  Not exactly spicy, but flavorful and delicious.  I come to Mexico au Parc when I want Mexican food, but don't want to be engorged afterwards.  It's a good option when you don't want a salad or sandwich at the park.
author: Jen C.

description:
The older burrito lady is just rude.  Twice now THEY'VE made the mistake and then give you the look of death when you ask them to make another one.

The burrito's generally taste good though.  Over $8 for a burrito with sour cream is too expensive, even for South Park area.
author: tim r.

description: A bit pricey, a long line if you visit right near noon -- but still the best Mexican you can get in the neighborhood if the taco trucks are nowhere to be found. Tough to find a seat so I'd recommend a to go order.
author: Brandon P.

description:
Just to be absolutely sure that I was making the right decision every week when I walk over to Victor's and order myself a big fat chicken mole burrito, I made the trek over to this joint. Uh yeah...I'm making the right choice w/ Victors. The chicken was just so-so, the guacamole was very bland, the whole experience in general left much to be desired. 

The only thing that Mexico au Parc has that Victor's doesn't is a nice looking little salsa bar (loved all the selections)! But there's no patio seating, there's definitely a lack of personal attention (never once did I get greeted with "Hola Guapa") and the food was mediocre at best. Not bad...just belongs more on a "dollar menu" at Taco Bell instead of having their own restaurant.
author: Kristy M.

description:
"Wah wah wah it's super yuppified and not authentic, whine whine bitch bitch moan moan."  Which is hilarious, because burritos are about as Mexican as Chop Suey is Chinese.  What MATTERS is how it tastes, if it's fresh, and if it's got those essential burrito elements - Mexican rice (no plain white rice - that's right I'm talking to you Chipotle!), good beans, cilantro, yummy salsa, and fresh guac (and good cheese and meat if you're into that kind of thing.)

On these points Mexico Au Parc delivers.  And for less than 5 big ones my tummy is happily stuffed, and my taste buds are smiling.  My only complaint is that I hate when places ask me if I want the spicy salsa and then it isn't even medium.  I don't know about anyone else, but THIS white girl can take the heat, so turn it up!

It's adjacent to the charming urban oasis that is South Park, so if it's a beautiful sunny day like today I recommend taking advantage of it and walking your burrito to the Park ("Parc" is French for park, for those of you who don't speak French.  Yeah, you're welcome.)

French name?  Effing yummy tofu ranchero in my burrito?  I don't care if it ain't "authentic" PUT IT IN MY BELLLLLLLLYYYYYYY, UNGH.
author: Ashley B.

description:
I don't know any other place in the city that can wrap an entire bowl of soup in a thin tortilla shell and pass it off as a burrito. Have a big spoon and tons of napkins because it is gonna be messy. You want avocado? Good luck.

I'd recommend swinging down to Victor's if you want a burrito around that rea in soma.
author: Larry O.

description:
This is a great spot for lunch.

The tacos are pretty decent size and come with grilled flavorful chicken.
They are reasonably priced.

The best part is the salsa bar and the bag of chips. Oh and the awesome park - South Park, especially on a nice day.
author: Chili B.

description:
A pretty legit taqueria, but be prepared to wait in line if you go during peak hours.  The burritos are fairly substantial, and the salsa bar is a nice touch.  The cola's come in glass bottles, so be prepared to bring a bottle opener to enjoy your drink, and fyi, if its a sunny day, try to stake out a place in the park, a bench if your lucky and enjoy people watching while attempting to scarf down whatever deliciousness you chose to consume.

If you're craving a ginormous burrito and a little South Park adventure, come here.
author: Erika C.

description:
Isn't that just about the best name for a restaurant? And before you get too excited, no, it's not French Mexican food.

Mexico au Parc is, however, the best taqueria in the South Park vicinity. Variables for taquerias include steamed versus grilled, the taste of the beans, the quality of the salsa. All three are met with excellence here, though they do steam the tortillas.

Extra points for location, cilantro, and jalapenos and onions at the salsa bar. Eating in the park on a nice day is highly recommended.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Mexico Au Parc is my favorite Mexican lunch spot in SOMA.  I usually come here once a week  to order my usual Regular burrito with Chicken Mole.  Their ingredients taste fresh and they're not afraid to serve you up healthy sized portions.

Update:  Lately, I've find myself complaining a lot about the portion size of the burritos.  It's almost like a tummy tuck where they fold the extra tortilla inside the burrito.  There have been times where I'm getting mouthful of tortilla, wth!
author: Steve D.

description: I ordered a burrito but everything inside were leaking out after the first few bites. In the end I was not eating a burrito, but a plate of rice, beans. I can't give more than two stars to a mexico restaurant if they don't know how to deliver a proper burrito. They added a small slice of lettuce on my burrito, but two stars remain to the place.
author: nn X.

description: Wow, a clean, authentic taqueria in South Park?  Decent enough food, excellent salsa.  Now, explain to me why the name is in French?
author: dan s.

description: They make the best quesadillas ($4.95 to $5.25)!  Good price for a warm lunch.
author: Kristen S.

description:
This is a surprising good discovery in a well hidden area of South of Market.  The interior is covered with a collection of art work on a pale mustard yellow palette walls.  You get a nice view of the park outside this establishment while you eat.  

I had ordered a rice, beans, and cheese burrito which turned into a huge ass roll.  It looked pretty damn plain until I got to the salsa bar and dressed it with the Verde salsa, chopped tomatoes and cilantro. Needless to say, I couldn't finish downing this burrito.

Trish ordered the nachos loaded with cheese, guacamole, sour cream, and all the dressings.  Her order looked and tasted better than mine.  You know what  I'm ordering the next time I come here...

Parking can be a hit or miss in this area.
author: Nanette L.

description:
Another place we go to almost every week - it's close, got a decent menu.  This place serves great quesadillas.  I always get mine on a whole wheat tortilla with chicken, veggies, and a scoop of guacamole.

I've never had the desire to try the burritos - they're way too big!  I got the enchiladas once but will never get them again because they were microwaved in a Styrofoam container!!  Toxic!!  I'd rather enjoy my food lukewarm than have it microwaved.
author: Conny W.

description: cool burrito joint for lunch. had the salmon burrito and thought it was pretty good. =) pretty neat salsa bar too.
author: Tiff W.

description:
My office just moved to the SoMa area, and I've been searching for good lunch spots that won't leave me broke.

This is one of the best places I've found so far.  The burritos are very good, and the prices are just like any other taqueria.
author: Chris Q.

description:
Just got back from what was probably the worst Mexican food experience I've had since I moved to SF 11 years ago! 

First off, Mexican food is supposed to be fresh, fast and fun to eat!  Mexico au Parc served none of these things.

The line moved fast, but when I went to order I wanted grilled chicken tacos. Well you can't order something grilled from the line I was in. So I had to go to the next line.  There is not clear signage explaining their bad organization either. Note: if you have to eat here don't order something grilled.

Here's why:

They wrote my order down on a  sticky note.  Well the sticky note must have gotten lost in the salsa because then I proceeded to wait 15 minutes for two tacos.  That's right folks, 15 minutes.  That's almost half a lunch time, for some people!  

I open up my to-go box to two of the nastiest looking tacos I've ever seen.  Nothing about it looked fresh, or fun to eat.  The meat wasn't even inside my taco, but haphazardly falling out of the taco.  The salsa (if you could call this salsa) looked more like pureed tomatoes from a can dating back to WWII.  The salsa tasted even worse-just jalepeno spice, nothing else. The tortillas tasted like they'd been through a washing machine they were so WET!  

So all and all, don't go here.  Eat somewhere else in the Park and actually enjoy your time there.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Their Mole is SOOO GOOD.
I love the flan also.

They are super sweet, and bare with my spanglish. I try really hard to break my order down for them in Spanish, and they correct me when I'm wrong. I like that!

Grab it to go on a sunny day during lunch, sit in south park, and love life.
Well, that's what I do!
author: Kellie P.

description: Closest thing to the Mexican food I miss in San Diego - love this place.
author: Sarah B.

description:
When I worked in SOMA, I used to have a colleague who was (and still is) a Mexico au Parc Fanboi. I mean, in a major way. Even now, he still talks about it. It's great food, and not very expensive. I usually ordered a quesadilla of some sort, though I always like their burritos as well. You have a fair number of options with the burritos. 

At lunch time, the line goes out the door; I recommend having either a late or early lunch if you intend to eat here, if at all possible. If not, that's ok too, it's well worth the wait. 

Mexico au Parc is definitely one of the best lunch spots in south park, perhaps the best.
author: Frank B.

description:
My regular (small) burrito that used to cost $4.95 is now about $6.50.  

Do you realize that is a 30% increase??  I realize costs are going up (so you tell us) but dammit there is a recession going on if you hadn't noticed and a 30% increase just lost you my business by at least (if not more than) 30%.

In fact, I've been back a total of 2 times since the increase and that's only because a co-worker insisted that we here for lunch.
author: Spicy T.

description:
Two words: Azteca Burrito.
Awesome mexican food. I love how many options there are for different meats prepared different ways. Beware of the long lunch line on Fridays.
author: Heather C.

description:
You'd think a joint named Mexico Au Parc would serve slices of bell pepper with an organic taquito garnish for $$$. Far from it. Mexico Au Parc is a little taqueria that offers hearty authentic fare on the cheap.

I work around the corner and come once every two weeks. I usually get a torta al pastor. The way they prepare it, I can't think of any way to make it better. Despite the long lines for lunch, the grill is usually free and I'm out the door in five minutes. (And even if you have to wait in that line, it moves fast.) The burritos are good, too; the super will last for at least two meals. I can't forget the people who make those meals--they always greet you warmly.

Mexico Au Parc is the epitome of sunny South Park. If I ever have one of those mornings when I'm banging my head against the keyboard, I come to Mexico Au Parc for a Mexican sandwich and a smile.
author: William L.

description:
I must say I love the South Park location.  Its got everything.  Its got this cute little park, an old, quieter neighborhoodly feel, and within walking distance of all the nicer, newer areas of the city.

I gave Mexico Au Parc a try today for takeout lunch.  It looked really nice and clean inside and I tried the cheese enchilada combo.  It was excellent...one of the better taqueria-type places I've been to in the city and not too greasy either, which is tough to find.  I also liked the prices. 

So, why, oh why do I give them 4 stars, do you ask?  Why don't they deserve a perfect score?  Well, their hours sort of suck.  They're open only for breakfast and lunch, from 8-4 M-F.  I live within walking distance as does a growing number of residents and I'd love to frequent this place for dinner or during weekends, but I can't because they're closed.  Also, I usually don't have the luxury to work from home, as I did today, to enjoy it.

Note to management:  Improve your hours.  Not only will you rake in more money, but you'll improve your Yelp score.....at least from this lone gringo!
author: Aaron M.

description:
The line's often going out the door at this popular eatery in South Park, but the turnaround's pretty great -- I'm often in and out within 8 minutes or so. Seating can be limited at peak times (between 12-1:30pm) but during the summer, most folks take their burritos to the sprawling lawn of South Park.   Their quesadillas are very good, especially the mushroom and shrimp.  Admittedly, the aguas frescas aren't nearly as thick and fresh tasting as the ones at Mijita -- they're a bit watered down.

They serve breakfast and it's  not the usual Mexican fare - one is the French toast made with sweet potato bread.
author: Vera D.

description:
South Park is my favorite destination for lunch. 
A little grassy oasis ringed by cute cafes. There is no better outside place in the area aside from the Crossroads garden. 

Mexico Au Parc  (I try not to get hung up on the fact that it has a French name, though the Romance languages section of my brain is screaming "Nooooo!") is the classiest Mexican around these parts.

The carnitas are canitastic! I always get the "tostada without the tostada" which is basically a big pile of rice, beans, meat, guacamole, lettuce, tomato, and sour cream since that deep fried bowl makes my arteries scream "Noooooooooo!" If you're ever hungover though, it is highly recommended. Basically like a big flaky, salty croissant. Mmmm. Even without the tostada it'll keep you going through the end of the day for $5.50.

They also do a fantastic shrimp quesadilla. Just like in Me-hee-co. You'll need a fork unless you intend to leave covered in cheese and sour cream.
author: Eli B.

description:
Mexico au Parc is across South Park from my office, and it's pretty inexpensive, so everyone who works here has pretty much eaten here at least a handful of times, if not several times a week.

The general attitude my coworkers and I seem to have is: "eh. if you're really hungry, and you haven't had it in a while, and you've got very little time to get what you REALLY want for lunch...then ok." 

It's actually more like, when you ask someone in the office what they're doing for lunch, and they kind of half-grimace/shrug and say "aa, Mexican I guess" then you know they're going to Mexico au Parc.

However, the lines are always out the door during lunchtime, so lots of people seem to like their food. 

But it strongly seems like there's MSG or some weird chemical in all their food. After every time I've eaten here, I've always felt sick to my stomach and kind of out of it afterward, regardless of whether it's a sope, a veggie burrito, a chile relleno platter, etc. It's almost like getting a contact high from really bad pot! Not only have I confirmed this feeling with others around the office, but I've heard people complaining of the same thing without my having mentioned it! Really weird. I'd be curious to see if anyone else has noticed this! 

While the food tastes Good to OK at the time, for me, the margin of utility diminishes almost instantly after the first few bites.By the time you're all done and it's sat for a few minutes, you might find yourself telling a coworker, "remind me not to eat there again." 

After all, like I said this place seems super popular, but it might be that many people go here out of convenience, as they do in my office. I don't recommend...you might feel queasy afterward!
author: Heidi G.

description:
this place serves up a pretty weak burrito to go, but it's the only Mexican place near South Park.  I still go there once a week for lunch since it is convenient, but I wouldn't recommend it for anything but convenience.  During the lunch hour, expect a line out the door.  It moves quickly and you can bypass it if you go to the grill for a quessadilla.

It's overpriced for Mexican food, but still cheaper than the other restaurants in the area.  Their quessadillas are okay, their tamales suck, and their regular and super burritos are bearable.
author: mark l.

description: My friend seemed to really enjoy his burrito, and I had the tortilla soup- it may just be a preference thing, but there was a lot of dark meat in the soup...i prefer more solid white meat. The prices were fair, the place seemed  clean.
author: Paula B.

description:
Food is decent...cheap.... But establishment is not very clean. 

I work in the area, so i've eaten here many times.....Everything was great until I found a 3" Bone (no joke) piece in my Super Taco.... Then on another occasion, I ordered a Tostada...I was just eating my way along when my fork poked into something hard.  I lifted the fork to find a huge STAPLE.  Ones from a corrugated box!  The copper colored ones!  

Ever since that, I only go once in a while and even then, I eat slowly to make sure I'm inspecting everything before it goes into my mouth.
author: R. F.

description:
OK, so I've only been here once, but damn, this place is legit.  I had a spicy chicken burrito, which is the kind with stewed (not grilled) chicken.  The chicken was moist and spicy, but not too spicy for me.  Add pinto beans, rice, salsa and guacamole, and I had a bomb on my hands.

Great things about my burrito:

1.  It was huge.  They use the really big sized tortillas and steam them so that they stretch and stuff.  All the more room for generous portions of filling.
2.  It didn't fall apart, and you could actually eat it with your hands (although it quickly becomes a fork and knife exercise at a moment's notice)
3.  The salsas and cilantro and side items are fresh and potent.
4.  The chips were good.  I was worried as they are dark and looked greasy but they're thin enough that they're not just grease crisps.

The bad:
1. The lines are huge if you get there during the lunch rush.  OK, that's not their fault, but it is a knock against if you are looking for a casual bite.  Maybe take it to go.
2. It's a bit spendy for a burrito.  More that 16 bucks for 2 burritos and a 
Snapple?  (Thanks, Mike.)  OK, they are huge, and the lines are out the door, so how can you blame them...
3.  This is one of those places that charges extra for items ala carte style.  20 cents extra for iceberg lettuce shreds?  I mean, why bother?

All and all, I'll be back.  Next time, burritos are on me, Mike!
author: Brad P.

description:
Really, this place is closer to a 3 food-tastiness-wise (or possibly lower due to that 'steamed broccoli burrito' which is an affront to my culture), but the fact that they offer cochinita pibil as a meat option made me lose my shit yesterday, so I'm giving it a 4. I haven't been that excited in a while. That's usually not offered at most Mexican places, unless they specialize in Yucatecan cuisine. I feel bad because I always get there right when they're about to close so the ladies working there give me an almost tired look as they prepare my order. Maybe that's why the food is kind of lukewarm as well? IDGAF though because I grubbed out on my cochinita torta yesterday afternoon in the park and it was fantastic. I don't know why there was cheese on there because it seemed wrong, but it was consumed so quickly I didn't really notice. But yeah, normally all that's on the torta is a black bean spread with red pickled onions. That's all you need, imo, as everything else seems rather superfluous. I was going to give this place a 3 based on the completely average shrimp burrito I had there once, but that was during Lent and I hadn't noticed cochinita was available (I suppose I was too weak from not eating meat to lift my head and read the menu properly.)

On a clear day, it's nice to take your food and eat across the street on the park benches. Definitely a good place for a quick bite.
author: Lilia M.

description: Every time I've eaten here it's been a completely different experience. Once it was fantastic, once I couldn't even finish because it tasted so bad (and I've been known to finish a pretty bad burrito just out of principle), and the rest of the time it's been decidedly mediocre. After I learned to ask them to hold the rice on my burritos things got better, but I'd generally rather go over to Maya when I need a quick Mexican fix for lunch in the South Park area. I was debating between three and two stars here but I'll go with three since they are next to the park, which is a fine place to spend your lunch on a nice day.
author: Mark A.

description:
Who doesn't enjoy a salsa bar? Its a sight rarely seen in the taquerias of San Francisco. BUT $7.75 for a super burrito? Come on.

I like their burritos, but I don't love them. 

On the plus side: They offer delicious breakfast burritos in the morning, and for lunch have a variety of burritos, tamales and sopes. While there is usually a long line, the people making your food are quick (the people ringing you up are slooooooooooow). It's a decent burrito if you go that route, not too greasy, can definitely grab it to go and avoid the post-burrito coma at work after.

On the downside: While they offer 15 different meat choices most of them are dry or flavorless. None of their salsas are spicy and the overabundance of rice doesn't add anything...but rice. Oh yeah, and they take way too long to cash you out when you have a burrito in your hand and are so hungry you'd happily eat the paperbag by the time you get to the register.
author: Kenny S.

description:
I almost ate here daily.
It's cheap, it's good mexican food, VERY fast service, and 4 minutes to my office, what else do I want more?

I like the ladies who work behind the counter when they yell at me "NEEEEEEEEEXXXXTTT" with a really low key. :)
author: Kerem S.

description:
They folded my burrito on the wrong axis!
All rice and beans at the top, all the good stuff in the middle - amateur move, usually made by the likes of Baja Fresh. That would never happen in the Mission, or at Victor's down the street.
They also forgot that I paid for guacamole and cheese, which took me almost half a burrito to figure out, because of the axis misconfiguration. When I went up to the counter to tell them, they gave me a tiny cup of guacamole, and no cheese. 
It also took them like 10 minutes to start making my order, even though it looked like there was surplus room on the grill. 
My coworker got a chicken burrito, and raved all the way through. Guess I should have stuck with a regular burrito instead of the grill.
author: Lee B.

description:
"Burritos" are to Mexico Au Parc as "little donkeys" are to Chipotle. 

Still, after being used to the efficiency of Chipotle, it's hard to approach any other burrito assemblage line and make sense of things. Really, you have to admit that Chipotle's got the order-a-burrito thing down well. Mexico Au Parc oddly has the tortilla steamer at the end of the line while the beans are at the beginning of the line -- a positioning that I like to think contributes to the awkward order line where you're bouncing back and forth in front of people as you try and pick out your beans (pinto) and meat (steak) and salsa (hot).  But what am I complaining about? It's a minor inconvenience for a rather tasty burrito. And if you're bored waiting in line, you can just look at the Diego Rivera prints on the walls. 

Bring cash. A burrito and a bottle of Jarritos falls below the $10 minimum purchase to use a card.
author: Tom N.

description:
This is officially my favorite taqueria in the land of wonderful, abundant, delicious taquerias. That is quite a recognition, as I used to eat at taquerias 4 times per week for many years. Then I moved out of SF into the land of Chipotle and Qdoba. Arghhh!

The veg options at Mexico au Parc are great, the food is fresh, the salsa bar offers five fantastic salsas. What else do you want in a taqueria? Horchata? I don't know if they have horchata... but the food is really good, and the salsas are great.

5 stars for a taqueria? Keep in mind, that is in the context of a taqueria. If good, fresh salsa is not important to you, then it's probably not worth trekking over here during the lunch rush. And, as far as I know, they close by 5pm, so dinner is not an option.

Unlike some of the cranky reviews here, I have never had any problem communicating with any of the restaurant staff. Getting a table, on the other hand, is always a challenge.
author: Channon H.

description:
Compared to Mission Burrito Joints: It's no Mission burrito joint (dirt-cheap-but-insanely-tasty) but 

Value: I like this place because I can get a decent lunch for under $5.  The veggie taco is huge and a fantastic deal for $2.80.

Variety: some interesting things like sopas, which is a johnny-cake made from masa (the same dough as corn tortillas), and chile rellenos.  

Cleanliness: everything's clean and fresh and you never worry about later that day when, you know, the food's past your stomach.

The Line:  it goes really fast, and now that they put in a smaller drinks cooler you can actually start mentally preparing before you hit the counter.

Join the rest of the yuppies from startups and design firms in line, folks!
author: Margot L.

description:
I used to like this place enough to eat there once or twice a week for lunch, but over the past month or two they've changed enough that I end up disappointed just about every time I eat here.  A few weeks ago they raised their prices, which is fine, they didn't even make them much more expensive.  But, the quality of the food went down dramatically.  The burritos used to be better than average for San Francisco, but now I can't think of a local place that has worse burritos than Mexico au Parc.  The main problem is that they started skimping on the fillings.  Their burritos used to be average size for an SF burrito, now they are about as big as those little frozen burritos you can get at a gas station for $2.

I was okay with the price hike, but when they lowered the quality of their product to go along with it my stomach just couldn't justify eating there anymore.  Not when I can go home and get a burrito from el Castillito on Church & Market that is twice as big, twice as tasty and costs $1 less.

If their burritos went back to their normal size I would be happy to start eating here again, but for now I'm taking my burrito dollars some place where they at least hook up a meal-sized burrito that will keep me full until dinner time.
author: John H.

description:
Despite the cornucopia of Diego Rivera paintings adorning the walls, this place never fails to satisfy when I'm in the mood for something heavy, cheesy and sleep-inducing.

A decent selection of vegetarian options.  I usually go for the veggie burrito which always tastes fresh--my only complaint is that they often skimp on the rice and go overboard with the beans.

Mushroom quesadillas are excellent as well but order them with the sour cream and guacamole on the side unless you're down with messy eating -- the sour cream melts and drips all over the place.
author: Jack G.

description:
+1 Star for delicious Al Pastor and chicken mole
+1 Star for delicious hommade chips and great salsa verde
+1 Star for being reasonable priced (VERY reasonably priced considering it's in South Park...Huge burrito for $5...where else you gonna eat for five bucks in this neighborhood?)
+1 Star for delicious aguas frescas
+1 Star for fast, friendly (albeit abrupt in the lunch rush) service
+1 Star for big menu variety
-1 Star for the bone in my Pastor and the huge line at lunch (which is just a testament to how ruling this place is)
= 5 stars
author: Alex K.

description:
Best burritos in SOMA.  I eat here a few times a month.

The burritos are big, well made, the ingredients are fresh, and the line moves quickly.

Only complaint is the seating inside is fairly limited, especially for groups larger than 4.
author: Ben B.

description: I like the food at this place very much; my only gripe is the seating -- very uncomfortable, especially when the place is crowded.  The tables and wooden benches can be cumbersome at times.  That said, the food is to be highly praised.
author: Guillermo G.

description:
I'm giving this place 1 star not because of the food (which is so so), but because of the shear incompetence and assinine way in which this restaurant is run.  To top it off, the staff are just rude and couldn't care less about customers.

  If you order certain kinds of burritos (it's not at all clear which ones), the ladies in the burrito line point to a different part of the restaurant, and tell you in their broken english "no order here, you order there".  

Of course "over there" there is no one to be seen, just an empty counter.  I tried going to said counter, but was completely ignored by every staff member that walked by.  Eventually I gave up and just went to the register, where the guy acted even more confused before finally taking my order.  This happened to the guy behind me too, who just gave up and pleaded, "ok, what am I allowed to order here?"  My burrito ended up being made in the back or something, and took 5x as long as the rest of my party, no explanation.

I will not be returning.  If you're going to have bizarre ordering rituals, you need to explain it somewhere on a sign, or at least have your staff speak enough English to explain what the hell is going on.
author: Kevin O.

description: Love the burritos but they make the worst tortas ever!  If you get them as take out they get soggy and messy.  You can't eat them to save your life.  To top it off they don't have a ham torta, WTF! they claim to be Mexican food joint and no ham torta???? lame!
author: Ern D.

description: Been here twice and each time the food has been very good.  I have tried their burrito and also the chicken quisadilla.  The prices are very reasonable.  You can order by the grill in the back of the restaurant or by the counter where you can custom order your burrito/taco/etc.  It's located at South Park in SOMA area of San Francisco.
author: R H.

description: There's something vaguely authentic about it -- they've got mole, nopales, and other such things -- and yet, it's really not all that interesting or flavorful.  No one's going to mistake South Park for Sinaloa, so I guess we all know that walking in...
author: Laurence W.

description:
when: weekday, lunch

This place is super close to my work, so a lot of my coworkers like to eat here. When I tried it, I ordered the super burrito, which I found more soggy than I would like it. The chips were alright, and the salsa was good. It fell apart and got pretty difficult to eat towards the end, and i usually handle my burritos well.

I went around lunch time and it was packed. The line was out the door. The place was packed and it was a little hard to move around. I dont recommend groups dining in during lunch on a weekday. A lot of the companies around seem to go to this place.

I havent tried Maya's yet, but I would make the walk out there to satisfy my craving.
author: Rena Y.

description:
I'm not a big fan of Mexican food.  I never was addicted to beans like many vegetarians; and while Mexican cooking is great for the lacto-ovo crowd it usually has next to nothing for vegans.

So when I saw the selection at this place, and it's close to my work, I had to try it.  I was a little disappointed though.  I got the tofu rancheros burrito, which i assumed would be spicy (and even asked for it spicy) but it was really bland.  It was really loud inside so maybe they got confused.  The portions are huge though.

I may try again, but for now i'm not super enthused.
author: Nessie V.

description:
Really close to my work, so I've been going here for a while - so far, so good.  Except the portions are huge and I've never seen anyone finish a burrito here.  Did I mention I work in an all-male office?

That's correct, none of the men I dine with daily can stomach a whole one.  Now that, is a fatty burrito.

Quality products from what my tummy can tell.

The nachos are also good and the mole, breakfast burritos (just as huge), and enchiladas - I rotate between them all.

They have a little salsa buffet to choose from and keep it brimming with choices.

The prices are also really good, especially for SOMA standards and the service is fast.

I recommend a late lunch if you want a place to sit, like 1:30 - 2(ish), otherwise you can post in on a bench in South Park or the grass - but I have seen suspiciously guilty looking dogs around the lawns at south park so be sure to sit on your coat or something.  Just a sense.
author: Lauren G.

description: Mexico au Parc what can I say about this place the food (well the burrito) was okay not great. But the wait for the burrito was like 45 min. Please do not go for the afternoon rush. The price is not so hot either it was $8.00 for a reg burrito. If you are not in a rush and want to check it out.
author: Dee Z.

description:
3.5 stars.
Very consistent. Crave it once every other week. More American than Mexican style Taqueria.  Good Tostada. Big burrito. Don't get the Fish taco. they just sort of slapped together like they didn't know what to do. Also wheat spinach and red pepper tortillas are available. Check it!

Just had the the breakfast burrito.  I highly recommend it as an early morning Mexican fix.
author: Adam L.

description:
Don't be fooled by the fancy name, while Mexico au Parc is not the much-loved divey taqueria, it is extremely affordable. They offer nice little touches like specialty tortillas and some unique menu items for vegetarians like my personal favorite, the tofu ranchero burrito, and they also serve my biggest mexican food vice: a chile relleno burrito.

If you're here on a sunny day, ditch the crowded interior and grab a bench or just lay on the grass at the park and spend a little one on one time with your burrito. You just might fall in love.
author: Kit K.

description:
Great burritos. Fast but not so friendly service.  The breakfast burritos are my favorite.  Must show up early to lunch or the line is out the door - but they still serve you pretty fast.  Prices are VERY reasonable for San Francisco.  

They also provide several types of salsa and free chips with every meal.
author: Jen W.

description:
It's lucky to exist on such a cute block, and seemingly be the most affordable, least thought-intensive food on said block. Someone correct me if I'm wrong, because I'm partial to South Park rather than anywhere on South Park.

It's a nice looking business and I ate there on a nice day and had a perfectly adequate burrito, so I wasn't particularly annoyed when I felt forgotten for minutes while an employee was apparently waiting for my cheese to melt or something?.
author: Brian S.

description: Excellent huevos rancheros for breakfast. Good salsa bar. Long line at lunch, but that is simply because they are very popular.
author: Helen L.

description:
this place is definitely nothing special. 

they are very lucky though in that they are in the south park area being a great location for a simple and fast lunch. they always have a long line at lunch time due to there not being too many good food choices in the immediate area. the prices are overpriced and the food is just whatever.

i work super close to this place but would rather walk a couple blocks to another mexican place instead of wait in line for a overpriced burrito.
author: Alex H.

description: Passable mexican for Soma standards. Iron Cactus and this place are about on par, with Iron Cactus getting extra points for having more variety and better service. Also the owner of Iron Cactus is my favorite guy ever.
author: Kevin L.

description: The last time I was here was 19 months ago.  It is good to see them still going strong.  Lunch time on a weekday they are packed.  The burritos they serve are made to order with you choosing exactly what you want inside.  Multiple types of tortillas, beans and meats.  They are made large enough to stand on end and easily be divided into lunch and then a snack later. Yum!
author: Hillary J.

description: As someone else already said... I like their burritos, but I don't love them.  What I do love, however, is getting burrito, raping the salsa bar and then having a nice lunch in South Park with the sun on my face.
author: Boots B.

description:
Stumbled across this place today when I decided I would finally figure out where Jeremy's was.  Well, yay, I found Jeremy's, but I didn't even go in because I'd already spent 20 minutes walking there and needed to eat and not spent 90 minutes on lunch.  So I walked back up South Park and ducked in here.

Had a steak fajita burrito that was as long as my forearm.  It was pretty good, although it was kind of bland even though I requested the hot salsa in the burrito. 

The small salsa bar has this fantastic red onion salsa.  It was a purplish tint, with a hint of jalapeno.  It was pretty amazing.  I'd probably return just for that.  The quesadillas looked good too.  

I liked how the walls were covered with prints of Diego RIvera, pictures of Frida Kahlo and other Mexican art.  Pretty classy joint.

----ETA - I just took a bite into the 2nd half of the burrito I couldn't finish (it's a few days later) and I found the hot salsa that didn't seem to be there before...would be nice if I could've had this when I was choking down the first bit.  The salsa's nice and hot though!
author: Charlotte M.

description:
Great hidden place to get a burrito in the SOMA area. But the long lines at lunch time suck!

Burrito's are mighty tasty!!! Their horchata drinks are delicious but I don't like chewing on the little seed things when it gets towards the bottom of the cup.
author: V M.

description:
Best taqueria in the area if you want good mexican food and it's really cheap too!  You get in line, order (don't mess up or they'll give you the look and probably call you an idiot), and zoom bam boom, next thing you know, you're sitting in south park, chilling out, and having a nice lunch under a beautiful sunny afternoon. 

I've also came here for breakfast and their burrito was really delicious.  For lunch, I normally get the super taco and the south of the border "Coke" because it tastes different than the gringo's version...if you work around this area, definately give it try, especially on a sunny afternoon.

Again, remember not to mess up your order and try to change it or you'll get a third degree disgruntled worker scolding.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Tasty lunchtime burritos for not very much money.  The veggie burrito's only $3.50 and there's a generous helping of chips to go with it.  The salsas are not labelled, so I ended up with two that were much less hot than I'd have preferred, but still tasted good.

Yum!
author: Apollo L.

description:
Good mexican, not great.

Everyone that works there is super efficient but a little bit cold.  Also, they don't put enough meat in the burritos!

Lots of complaints but it's still the best, if not only, Mexican within walking distance.
author: Alexander T.

description:
I jokingly call the food here "Frenchican" since their name is in French.  I have only had their chicken quesadilla and super steak burrito, and both were good.  You definitely get your bang for you buck here in terms of portions and price, especially for the South Park area.

A line tends to form out the door during the lunch rush hour, so it is best to go either before or after the 12-1 block.
author: Marlon E.

description:
The only burrito joint in the SOMA for lunch with a reasonable price and good flavor for your azz. Carnitas is kickin'. Sometimes I'll hit the wet burrito if I'm feelin' like my stomach needs its horizon expanded.

Lots of things are good here, actually. Check the grill.
author: André C.

description: I liked this place. I was a bit early for lunch and it was not crowded. The lovely owner gave me a sample taste of the pork. Yum! I ended up with two tacos,  shrimp and chicken, which were fine but a bit sparse. My other complaint was that the food (esp the pork and chicken) seemed very salty. With that said, I would try it again.
author: Jill D.

description: Honestly, this may be one of the worst Mexican places I've been to. I've tried it three times, each time coming away with a stomachache and a huge pile of soggy "mexican food". I've tried the burrito, the sope and the tacos. None were good - all were soggy messes of flavorless meats/beans/cheese. This place reminds me of the places that masqueraded as "mexican" in NY (Yes, burritoville, I'm talking to you). Three times the charm. Not coming back here.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I'm not really a big fan of mexican food, since I try to eat light.  I recommend the Paradise Salad - lots of baby greens with cojita cheese, grilled mexican seasoned chicken, and walnuts with a light balsamic vinagrette.  

I really didn't expect this kind of quality on a salad from a mexican place.  Most lo-cal options tend to be unimaginative and uninspired - this item is the exception.
author: Timothy D.

description:
So tasty and delicious.  I love this place.  Great Mexican food.  I especially recommend that big ass burrito they make.  The special.  Covered in sauce and cheese.  Yeees.  

And as I'm always a big fan of tacos, I can heartily recommend those there too.  Especially the chicken in green sauce (hell if I can remember what to call it.  Verde???) 

Although the name has always boggled my mind just a little bit.  French?!?
author: April B.

description:
Best burrito this side of the Mission.  I stop in here about once a week for a tasty lunch with south of the border ingredients and north of the border sensibilities.  Sure the line is out the door, but the burrito elves work hard behind the glass to get everyone fed in time for their 1 PM conference call.

I usually order the super-veggie but I've tried the meat versions including carnitas, mole and stewed chicken - all are great.  Oh, and don't be too distracted by the burrito line that you overlook the quesadilla queue.  You can get almost any of the meats grilled fresh and prepared as a quesadilla or tossed in a burrito or taco.

There's usually a friendly, smiling person at the cash register who's all too happy to top off your bag with chips.  And there's a respectable assortment of fresh salsas and condiments available including fresh cilantro, limes and chiles.

Mexico au Parc is au right with me.
author: Brian C.

description:
This is currently my favorite burrito joint. They are authentic and a model of efficiency.

The burritos are excellent and South Park rules.  Oh, and how cool is it that they have some French in their name.
author: Narendra R.

description:
I frequented this place for lunch when I was at school all day, and each time it made me wonder why I hadn't tried it sooner.  The quesadillas are amazing! The taco salad (I don't think it's on the menu but you can ask for it) is really good too.  I was a bit disappointed with the veggie burrito, but maybe it's better with meat.

They take credit cards if you spend a minimum of $8, though they don't seem to strictly enforce that rule.  Awesome!  It can get crowded during lunchtime so it might be a good idea to get your order to go, but at least the line moves quickly.  I wish their hours were longer too... I want a quesadilla for dinner too, dammit!
author: Nicole z.

description:
Call me a taco snob, but I always find it amusing that so many people who eat at a Mexico restaurant, or even a taqueria, only seem to order burritos. So the fact that most of the reviews for Mexico au Parc are in regards to their burritos is not unexpected. What is surprising is the fact that not many people have mentioned the Grille!!!

If you want to know why I'm giving Mexico au Parc 5 perfect stars, pay the extra few cents for their steak tacos hot off  the Grille (as opposed to their "regular" taco, which I have to agree was rather regular). It was quite possibly the best taco I've ever tasted.
author: Yuffie G.

description:
Show up early (11:30) to skip the line. It stays busy until around 2pm. If you have to go during lunch hours the line can be pretty daunting but it goes fast so if you're not claustrophobic you can go for it or skip the line by walking to the grill in the back right of the space. The al pastor here is great and the meat is quality.

The tacos and plain veggie burritos are inexpensive and light. For a larger meal get a super burrito. 

If you get a bottle of coca cola, grab a lime wedge at the salsa counter for the ultimate beverage.
author: George M.

description:
For Mexican this is tops; great people, great food, real fast service. I love stopping in here. The format is cafeteria style; grab a trey and stand in line.  Even when the line is out the door the service is very fast and you can have your food in 10 min max.  This place is no frills but the food is authentic, good quality and yummy.  They also serve breakfast as well; I tried the egg / spicy sausage burrito and it was also good although your doctor may recommended you start saving for a heart transplant if you eat these things more than once a month.

Recommended for lunch if you are in the area.
author: Brian K.

description:
This place is not bad.  A bit overpriced, especially when compared to the mission, but this is downtown in a prime location.  Close to the ballpark and the technology sector I expect everything to be twice as expensive and half as good.

Mexico au Parc is good and would be right at home around similar fare on Valencia.  Everything costs a couple dollars more.  I have to commend them for their choice of different meat types.  Mole, green mole, marinated carnitas.  These all make for a more interesting burrito, even if a little heavy on the sauce sometimes.  

The staff is always quick and I've never had any bad experiences here.  Its pretty much my go to place for Mexican food in the area.
author: James A.

description: Uninteresting burrito, but the service that I have gotten here has been horrible. The last time I went there I wanted a regular burrito with no beans. Than they called me to get my order and told me that I have to pay extra. Huh? The reason is that they made me an Super Burrito with bean instead of a regular burrito with no bean. I told them I prefer that they remake a burrito for me because I do not eat bean. The cashier person angrily told me, "Fine than, but you will have to wait at least 15 minutes," but the restaurant was pretty much empty. Why punish me for your mistake?
author: Erica B.

description:
Awesome salsa bar and sopes with 7 or so different meat options, What's a sope? It's this chewy fried masa base that acts as a free for all toppings. The best $3 meal in SOMA period.

*Burritos are average. I'm sure there are better places in the Mission for that.
author: Hyan K.

description:
This place is awesome!!! Newly working in the SOMA area, I was having a craving for burritos, my co-worker brought me here and I was hooked!! Coming from the Central Valley, I have high standards for Mexican food, and this surpassed my expectations. 

The super veggie burrito is great, and the fact that you can choose your tortilla was just an added bonus. 

This restaurant has a quick and efficient method of getting you in and out with your food. There has been a line out of the door every time i have visited, but I have never had to wait for more than a few minutes. 

Plus there is South Park right outside the front door which is a great place to enjoy your awesome burrito. I can't wait to bring my husband here!
author: Jen T.

description: Any place with a salsa bar does a Mexican restaurant justice. I am proud to call this place my "neighborhood restaurant" because it's really good. Hands down the best Mexican food in SoMa. It's not Mission Mexican, but it's damn close. The shrimp quesadillas and the azteca burrito are favorites. If there's room, try the flan. Prices are moderate, but the portions make up for it. Lines are usually out the door for a reason. For quality food, Mexico au Parc is worth the trip.
author: Alex H.

description: The food isn't outstanding, but they do a solid burrito, they do it quick and they consistently get it right. This is definitely a frequent lunchtime spot for me.
author: Michael A.

description: This is the best mexican food in the area. It certainly is better than Victor's.
author: Sergio G.

description:
Tried a nice "lil" burrito the other day.  Totally stuffed.  Not at all the traditional mexican style burrito (lettuce?  seriously?) but it hit the spot.
Can't complain about quality of taste (though I didn't expect it to taste so...American) or price so this place deserves the four stars easily.  

SOMA is notoriously expensive (as you can tell from all my bitching and moaning on Yelp) and South Park even worse so THIS is solid.
author: Sean M.

description:
Right in the middle of an ideal location, Mexico au Parc is a nice place to grab lunch from. The place itself isn't very large, but unfortunately, they've stuffed every space they can with tables. Thus, its cramped to eat in there. If you get a table, make sure you have everything you need like salsa, napkins, etc, because getting out and back to your table is a labor of Hercules. 

The service is ok, but I think the women behind the counter is so used to the routine that if you change from the standard burrito, pay attention to them making it! Still, the burritos are darn good. I really don't care if its really authentic, it tastes good with the right ingredients. The best and second appeal to Mexico au Parc is the park. Great place to get one of the few tables there on a nice afternoon. Being stuffed in the office all day, its nice to get outdoors for a while.

In the end, Mexico au Parc gets good marks for the location and burritos. Its a definite add on your list of lunch places in the area.
author: Ivan M.

description:
I've been going to this place for over five years and still love their food!  I usually do lunch here and pick up a breakfast burrito on occasion.  Their quality is consistent evidenced by the crowd every day.  

Highlights: never gotten sick here!
Favorite: chile relleno dinner
Note: head straight to the grill if you want any "grill" items, the line out the door is for burrito and other menu items
author: Vivian H.

description: Delicious! Had the chicken quesadilla  with guacamole. the tortilla was crispy, the meat flavorful.
author: Rachel Q.

description:
A top-notch, higher food quality, taqueria. Not your mission-style grease-fest. It definitely caters to the SOMA work crowd, but worth the walk from Market if you're looking to get out of the office for a longer lunch. 

If you mistime your meal and go during the lunch rush, the line can spill out the door. It shouldn't take more than 10 minutes to get your food, but seating is sparse given the crowd. On a nice day you can take your plate or order to go and sit outside in the park.

Expect to spend $7-$8 on a burrito and another $2 for a drink. They have tasty agua frescas.
author: Benny B.

description: I have eaten lunch here maybe 6-7 times and I have only had various chicken buritos because they are so good why switch?  Price is right....only $6.25 and a coke is like a buck.  Yo have to get there by like 12:15pm to get a seat as this place gets packed.   Great value and better than many more expensive places.
author: Mark M.

description: Long lines during lunch but worth the wait.  This place is a staple among my co-workers.
author: Carrie L.

description: Friendly service (at least at the register, from who I assume is the owner) and the best super vegetarian burrito in the area. Usually too packed to find a seat at lunchtime, but the park outside offers plenty of benches.
author: Lauren B.

description: Place has good burritos. Really tasty and most importantly not greasy like a lof mexican food I've had. They do a good job of getting you in and out  pretty quickly even during lunch traffic. Reasonably priced and nice location where you can get it to go and go eat in the lovely South Park.
author: Kyle B.

description: I love this place. It's great Mexican food. It's kinda squishy and hard to get a seat during the lunch hour. It's pretty packed. But what do expect when you have good Mexican food. They have a GREAT tostada.
author: Jessica P.

description: I love coming to my place for one thing only. Their tacos and bbq (barbaqua) pork. I've lived in TX and nothing can compare how succulent their bbq pork are purely the bomb. Mission St shops got nothing on them.
author: Daniel K.

description: I adore this place. For all those other vegans out there, they have tofu rancheros! It is so good, and their beans don't have lard! I also love their salsa, but they don't automatically put any veggies on the tofu rancheros burrito, so here is what I do. I get it with the pico de gallo salsa (to add the freshness of the tomatoes), then I get a bunch of little containers of the spicy salsa and put that on top... so yummy. Also, get the guac on your burrito. It's worth it!
author: Jeani H.

description: Their Al Pastor is some of the best I have had and it's cooked to order! The thing I like most about their al pastor is you can taste some sweetness which I want to say is pineapple in the marinade (very traditional). I always have them throw it in a super burrito which in my opinion is the best burrito of the three establishments in the area... not that there is much competition since Victors is awful. I only subtracted a star because it is a bit pricey (most likely due to the location), they do not have Tapatio sauce and I sometimes get shorted on chips. Otherwise, Mexico au Parc is your best bet for Mexican in SOMA.
author: Mark B.

description:
Months ago, on May 6th, a co-worker wanted to go here, but was avoiding it because of legit fear of running into an ex, who worked down the street and frequented it.  As a team, we were very persuasive and said that if we ran into said ex, the co-worker would be seen with _new_ friends (us) and, if worse came to worse, we'd totally throw down.  No one messes with our teammates!

So there was a line when we got there, as this place is quite popular, and not just because it's right next to one of the finest outdoor seating areas in the city.  We're waiting in line, just outside the door (moves pretty fast though), and who do we see coming down the street but the ex (we had calculated the odds, and they were good that our paths _would_not_ cross that day).  I had personally met this person a few times, and I know our cover was blown as a quick conversation took place among the co-workers of the ex.  There was a slight nod to me as they walked past, but we had a pretty uneventful lunch.  Later, we find out that we were apparently encroaching on the ex's lunch territory (I'll have lunch anywhere I damn well please, thank you very much), and all the ex wanted to do was have a burrito in peace.  Apparently, a "sammich" [sic] was purchased instead at some other, unknown, establishment.

Fast forward seven months.  I'm at a different job, with a new set of co-workers.  I'm telling my best buddy that we need to go here, but I couldn't remember the name, only the location ("Dude, I'm telling you, it's at South Park, I swear there's a good burrito place there!").  After about 4 weeks of convincing, and tracking the place down, we go.  It is awesome.
author: Andy B.

description:
A Little Mexico Au Parc translation:

tostada=taco salad.  I stopped ordering the burrito, because the Tostada just takes the same ingredients and puts them in an easy to eat DEEP FRIED crispy shell.  Yum, Yum.  

Also, this is one of the few places I'll actually drink a coke, because they stock the kind made in Mexico (Hecho en Mexico) con sugar AKA Cane Sugar, NOT High Fructose Corn Syrup.  Yum, tastes like when I was a kid.

Sadly, though, the portions are so great that this is a once :::burp::: in a while treat.
author: Mel B.

description: I drove around for a while trying to figure out what i wanted to eat... glad i picked this place, had a fantastic tosdada! All fresh and a great selection of salsas/sauces.
author: Rachel L.

description: This place is a well oiled machine. The staff is amazing and efficient. The line looks long, but it goes by pretty fast. Agua frescas were really amazing. So good I had two. They have a varied selection of salsa. Delicious!. We took our lunch to south park and had an impromptu hootenanny. My coworker brought her guitar and we rocked out and sang total eclipse of the heart and a few original racy originals.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Best place in SOMA if you don't want to run over to the Mission. Where else can you have a burrito in the park and play on swings or slide down a slide? 

Don't forget to get the chips at the counter!
author: bryan s.

description: I'm going to go ahead and drop the title of Best Mexican in Soma on this place.  Its not mission Mexican, but its close.   I have had two very non-whitewashed meals here and I'm looking forward to a third.  The place is always packed at lunch with a long line, but somehow we are always able to get a table.
author: Todd F.

description: I come here about once a week for lunch, and I've gotta say- the burritos are full of more savory meaty goodness than I've had in all my adventures in the Mission. Ok, well maybe that's an exaggeration...but still- a damn fine burrito will be had here!
author: Rebecca F.

description: I love this place. Everything is good and fresh and I'm getting my money's worth. The sopes are so good and so filling.  And, the lemonade is to die for.  A stellar choice is the grilled quesadilla, really top notch and they give you a ton of chips with your oder.  I love this place but my waistline doesn't...
author: OakMama D.

description:
They serve definitely better-than-average Mexican food.  No complaints about their service, etc...  Then why 3 stars? 

I had a burrito one day with my co-workers and well, we got the same thing - burrito with carne asada, one of my favorites.  But one devil came close to my ear and he said "why don't you spend a few extra bucks for Horchata?" - this is typical Mexican drink made with rice and I like it so much as well as Jamaica (pronounced as "Ha-my-ka" - remember you are in a Mexican restaurant :) 

Anyway, I kept working after my lunch and wow - the experience I had on the same afternoon was something that I would never forget!  I won't talk about details but all I can say is that I took out everything I ate on the same afternoon.  

My friend was completely ok and so I think it was Horchata - but you know, I think I will still go back to get it one day.  Just promise me that you are going to keep it fresh and refrigerate it!  

(The worst experience I had in Mexico was also from ice so this case could have been ice.  I won't sue you guys so be a bit more careful please!  I think their food is ok because Mexican food is cooked completely with heat usually.)
author: T T.

description: Burritos as big as your arm. Nuff said.
author: Yusuf B.

description: Decent burritos at great prices. Not sure about including lettuce in the burrito, but I just asked for it without it. My biggest complaint is the meat for the burritos isn't cooked fresh and is instead sitting in the metal tins and then thrown directly in the warmed tortilla. This would be fine for most of the meat, but the carnitas could've used a little cooking to make it crispy. The salsa however, is fresh and extremely spicy (especially the verde).
author: Nicolas H.

description: best burrito in the area.  I like the tostadas and the salsa is dope too.  also pretty fair prices for the area and in terms of food to belly ratio the best deal in that area for sure. except HRD but that is another story.  the carnitas is off the hook and that is most difficult meat to cook right.  I have had some shitty carnitas in SF but this place rocks 8 out of 10times I go there.  good chips too and a grill too.   The place is usually pretty busy during lunch but they move people through there pretty fast.  burrtios under $6 .
author: Bucky W.

description: Had a couple of tacos there, which were really good.  And not your usual chicken/pork/beef choices.  There was a cochinita pibil which was really good and a chicken mole that was good as well.  Pretty crowded at lunch, and a bit disorganized, but in a nice location and if there are no seats, you can get it to go to eat in the parc.
author: Mike B.

description:
Poor burrito contruction. A bean and rice burrito ("vegetarian" on their menu) was about half the size of the other burritos, and poorly drained pinto beans lead to squishy burrito leakage. One of my coworkers got a chicken super burrito that ruptured near the bottom while she was eating it, spilling burrito juice everywhere.  They definitely need to rethink their construction strategy.

Flavor wise, the burrito was ok. Nothing mind blowing, maybe not worth the long walk from my office (we passed another taqueria, Victor's, on the way over but heard this place was better).

The salsa verde rules, which made my day. Nothing makes a so-so burrito taste better than good salsa..
author: a a.

description: I really like the chile verde burritos here. It would be nice if the chips where a bit thicker/ fresher.
author: Matt L.

description: This is definitely the best burrito place you can find in the neighborhood.  While the line gets super long during lunch time, it moves quick and is well worth the wait.  They have seating inside, but you can also cop a squat right out the door in SBC park with all the other start-up employees in the neighborhood.
author: Jeni D.

description: It was my last day in California and I was feeling nervous. Why? I hadn't yet crossed one of the most important items off my to-do list- eat some killer mexican on the cheap! I was headed back to New England in a matter of hours! This place is close to my friend-and-host's school and is one of her favourite haunts. And I'm happy to report that it totally delivered the goods for me in the form of a slammin' al pastor burrito and some homemade horchata. Could we have found some place more "authentic?" Perhaps. But I would've been hard pressed to find something tastier. Call it mission accomplished, without actually venturing into the mission.....
author: Greycella L.

description: Pretty decent burrito. They are filled pretty full of stuff and not wimpy like some other places I've been to. Their tortillas are pretty thin, which I sorta like, but sometimes the burrito fillings bust through because of this and then you have a sloppy mess on your hands. Make sure you have napkins on hand!
author: Cathy M.

description: White boy mexican food at it's most stereotypical.  I always hear from people in my office that the coolest thing about this place is the salsa bar, sadly this is little more than a bland collection of variations on pico.  All watered down and NOTHING approaching a hot sauce.  They try to make up for this by giving out bigger portions but all you end up with is more of the tasteless food you started off with.  If you find yourself near this place and are hellbent on mexican, it's worth the extra 5 minute walk to go down to victors on townsend or up to Maya on 2nd.  Either place offers better food than this place.
author: Matthew L.

description: Despite the long line, which formed quickly out the door right around 12PM on a Tuesday, the efficient service had us walking to our table with our order within 10 minutes.  Looked like many took their lunches "to go" to soak in the sun at the park across the way; otherwise, seating is probably hard to come by on cooler days, so come early.  We enjoyed our flavorful Super Burritos (w/chicken) and refreshing lime juice, which came with complimentary chips and a wide selection of salsa.  May get more authentic and cheaper stuff in the Mission, but this seemed reasonable by SOMA standards.  Took home leftovers for another meal.
author: Squeaks L.

description: Solid Mexican food near my work.  Certainly not my favorite burrito in the city, but it works for a tasty lunch.
author: David S.

description: Ala my other three, this is a 2.5/3.  It is good, really it is...I just have trouble ranking a South Park burrito a 3 or above.  I am a man who likes his Mexican food authentic and legit...I just can't get where I work.  This recommendation is if you are in the area. (south park). If you're not,. go to the Mission and go to Taqueria Altena or somewhere fo' real.
author: Craig R.

description: Yet another great restaurant in South Park. While it's well organized for the lunch crowd, it isn't open on the weekends and closes (oddly) at 4:30. Has spinach, whole wheat, tomato, and flour tortillas. Only problem with the burritos is that cheese is extra; my biggest burrito annoyance. Overall good,  esp since burritos come with free chips and salsa.
author: Mairead J.

description: HUGE burritos at reasonable prices. One of the better Mexican places in the SoMA area; always top of mind when you can't make it all the way to the Mission for lunch during a work day.
